I found comprehensive information about Claude Code subagent file format and structure. Here's what I discovered:

## Subagent File Format Structure

Each subagent is defined in a Markdown file with YAML frontmatter using this structure:

```markdown
---
name: your-sub-agent-name
description: Description of when this subagent should be invoked
tools: tool1, tool2, tool3  # Optional - inherits all tools if omitted
model: sonnet  # Optional - specify model alias or 'inherit'
---

Your subagent's system prompt goes here.
```


## File Locations

Subagents are stored as Markdown files with YAML frontmatter in two possible locations:
- **Project-level**: `.claude/agents/` (in your project directory)
- **User-level**: `~/.claude/agents/` (global across all projects)(no content)When subagent names conflict, project-level subagents take precedence over user-level subagents.

## Key Components

**YAML Frontmatter Fields:**
- `name`: The subagent's identifier
- `description`: Tells Claude when to invoke this subagent
- `tools`: Optional tool restrictions (inherits all if omitted)
- `model`: Can use aliases (sonnet, opus, haiku), 'inherit', or omit for default

**System Prompt:**
The system prompt can be multiple paragraphs and should clearly define the subagent's role, capabilities, approach to solving problems, specific instructions, best practices, and any constraints the subagent should follow.

## Creation Methods

You can use the `/agents` command in Claude Code to create new subagents interactively.

        

    

    

    

    
    
    
    
    

        

            üõ†Ô∏è WebFetch
            

                

                    2025-11-05 09:00:44
                

                
            

        

        

            

                url
                https://docs.claude.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents
            

        
            

                prompt
                
                    

                        Extract the complete information about subagent file format, including: 1) YAML ...
                        
Extract the complete information about subagent file format, including: 1) YAML frontmatter fields and their allowed values, 2) available model options, 3) available color options for subagents, 4) any examples of subagent files, 5) tool specifications, 6) best practices for creating subagents

                    

                		
            

        

    

    
    
    
    
    

        

            
            

                

                    2025-11-05 09:00:54
                

                
            

        

        

    

        
            
# Subagent File Format Guide

## YAML Frontmatter Fields

Based on the Claude Code documentation, subagent files use Markdown with YAML frontmatter containing:

**Required fields:**
- `name`: "Un...

        
        

            
# Subagent File Format Guide

## YAML Frontmatter Fields

Based on the Claude Code documentation, subagent files use Markdown with YAML frontmatter containing:

**Required fields:**
- `name`: "Unique identifier using lowercase letters and hyphens"
- `description`: "Natural language description of the subagent's purpose"

**Optional fields:**
- `tools`: Comma-separated list of specific tools (inherits all if omitted)
- `model`: Model selection option

## Model Options

The `model` field accepts three types of values:

1. **Model aliases**: `sonnet`, `opus`, or `haiku`
2. **`'inherit'`**: Uses the same model as the main conversation
3. **Omitted**: Defaults to the configured subagent model (typically `sonnet`)

The documentation notes that using `'inherit'` ensures "consistent capabilities and response style throughout your session."

## Tool Specifications

Subagents can access any of Claude Code's internal tools. You may:

- **Omit the tools field** to inherit all tools from the main thread (default behavior)
- **Specify individual tools** as comma-separated values for granular control

MCP tools from configured servers are automatically included when the tools field is omitted.

## File Structure Example

```markdown
---
name: agent-identifier
description: When and why to use this agent
tools: Tool1, Tool2, Tool3
model: sonnet
---

Your system prompt describing the agent's role, 
capabilities, and problem-solving approach.
```

## Best Practices

The documentation recommends:

- Creating focused agents with single responsibilities rather than multi-purpose ones
- Writing detailed system prompts with specific instructions and constraints
- Limiting tool access to only necessary capabilities
- Version-controlling project-level subagents for team collaboration
- Starting with Claude-generated agents, then customizing for your needs

Based on the search results, I can provide you with information about Claude Code subagent color options:

## Claude Code Subagent Colors

When creating custom subagents in Claude Code, you can select a color to assign to the subagent, which will be displayed when you call the subagent in the main conversation session, making it easier to visually identify which subagent you have called.

### Key Points About Colors:

1. **Color Selection During Creation**: You can pick the color of your agent as part of the subagent creation process through the `/agents` command.

2. **Visual Identification**: The user experience is well-designed, allowing you to select a background color to easily distinguish between sub-agents visually as you watch Claude Code work.

3. **Purpose**: You choose a color for visual identification when multiple agents run simultaneously.

4. **Customization Options**: You can optionally pick a color or icon for easy recognition.

### Important Notes:

- The search results don't specify the exact list of available colors to choose from in 2025
- There's an open feature request from August 2025 asking to use agent colors in the list that shows up in /agents, so users wouldn't have to grep the agents folder for color before creating a new one
- Colors are stored in the agent configuration files and can be edited manually

The color feature is designed to help you track which specialized subagent is currently working when you have multiple agents handling different tasks in parallel workflows.

                        Extract all information about available color options for Claude Code subagents,...
                        
Extract all information about available color options for Claude Code subagents, including the complete list of color names that can be used

# Claude Code Subagent Colors

Based on the provided GitHub issue content, **no specific color options or a complete list of available colors for Claude Code subagents is documented**.

The feature re...

        
        

            
# Claude Code Subagent Colors

Based on the provided GitHub issue content, **no specific color options or a complete list of available colors for Claude Code subagents is documented**.

The feature request from user lelandg (August 6, 2025) simply requests that agent colors be displayed in the `/agents` command output. The issue states: "It would be cool to use agent colors in the list that shows up in `/agents`. Then I wouldn't have to grep the agents folder for color before I create a new one!"

This indicates:
- Colors **currently exist** for agents in configuration files
- Users must currently search agent folders to discover available color options
- The requested enhancement would make these colors visible in the CLI interface

The issue itself contains **no enumeration of available color choices**. To find the actual color palette, you would need to consult the Claude Code documentation, source repository, or agent configuration files directly.

I found several search results about Claude Code subagents and their YAML frontmatter configuration, including information about the `color:` field.

Here are the key findings:

## YAML Frontmatter Structure for Claude Code Subagents

The YAML frontmatter format for Claude Code subagents includes required and optional fields: `name` (required unique identifier), `description` (required short description), `model` (optional), `tools` (optional list), `disallowedTools` (optional list), and `color` (optional for UI display).

## The Color Field

The built-in Claude Code agents include a color reference in the frontmatter, and each agent file must follow the YAML frontmatter format with `name`, `description`, and `color` fields.

Examples from the search results show various colors being used:
- The Mend security assistant uses `color: blue`
- A proofreader agent example uses `color: orange`
- A backend architect example uses `color: cyan`

## Documentation Gap

Interestingly, there appears to be no official documentation regarding the `color:` frontmatter syntax definition, despite extensive searching. This was even noted as a bug/documentation issue in the Claude Code GitHub repository.

The general structure is:
```yaml
---
name: agent-name
description: Description text here
color: color-name
---
```

        

    

    

    

    
    
    
    
    

        

            üõ†Ô∏è WebFetch
            

                

                    2025-11-05 09:02:19
                

                
            

        

        

            

                url
                https://gist.github.com/bartsmykla/d7dfca753dae6d20cd58b018b0d7c6dd
            

        
            

                prompt
                
                    

                        Extract all information about Claude Code subagent colors, including any lists o...
                        
Extract all information about Claude Code subagent colors, including any lists of available colors, color field syntax, and examples of color usage in subagent files

                    

                		
            

        

    

    
    
    
    
    

        

            
            

                

                    2025-11-05 09:03:39
                

                
            

        

        

    

        
            
# Claude Code Subagent Colors

Based on the provided documentation, information about subagent colors is minimal:

## Available Information

The guide mentions a **color field** in the agent configura...

        
        

            
# Claude Code Subagent Colors

Based on the provided documentation, information about subagent colors is minimal:

## Available Information

The guide mentions a **color field** in the agent configuration frontmatter:

> "Optional: Color for UI display
> color: blue"

However, the document provides **no comprehensive list** of available color options beyond this single example showing "blue."

## Color Field Syntax

The color configuration appears as a simple optional parameter in the YAML frontmatter of custom agent files located in `.claude/agents/` directories.

## Limitations

The documentation does not elaborate on:
- Which colors are supported
- How colors are displayed in the interface
- Color naming conventions
- Default color behavior if unspecified

The guide focuses primarily on agent functionality, tool access, and model selection rather than UI customization through colors. To discover the full range of available colors, consulting the official Claude Code documentation or examining existing agent examples would be necessary.

Links: [{"title":"Claude Brand Color Codes ¬ª BrandColorCode.com","url":"https://www.brandcolorcode.com/claude"},{"title":"Claude Brand Color Palette: Hex, RGB, CMYK and UIs","url":"https://mobbin.com/colors/brand/claude"},{"title":"Custom agents with Claude Code and Otto","url":"https://www.ascend.io/blog/custom-agents-with-claude-code-and-otto"},{"title":"Claude Created Color Copier","url":"https://frankwiles.com/posts/claude-created-color-palette/"},{"title":"claude Color Palette","url":"https://www.color-hex.com/color-palette/78735"},{"title":"Claude AI Logo Color Codes, Fonts & Downloadable Assets - Begins w/ AI","url":"https://beginswithai.com/claude-ai-logo-color-codes-fonts-downloadable-assets/"},{"title":"Ralph Lauren Claude / RLVM250 / #d5c798 Hex Color Code, RGB and Paints","url":"https://encycolorpedia.com/d5c798"},{"title":"Claude Theme - Visual Studio Marketplace","url":"https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=Lumidew.claude-color-theme"},{"title":"Fixing Claude Code‚Äôs ‚ÄúFlat‚Äù or Washed-Out Remote Colors | by Martin Thorsen Ranang | Medium","url":"https://ranang.medium.com/fixing-claude-codes-flat-or-washed-out-remote-colors-82f8143351ed"},{"title":"Claude‚Äôs search for an accessible color triad | by Theresa-Marie Rhyne | UX Collective","url":"https://uxdesign.cc/claudes-search-for-an-accessible-color-triad-e07f7d8aab2e"}]

I found information about Claude Code and color options! 

When using Claude Code with custom agents (such as with Otto), you can choose from several background colors including: Red, Blue, Green, Yellow, Purple, Orange, Pink, and Cyan. The search results show there's also an "Automatic color" option available.

This appears to be related to configuring custom agents in Claude Code, where you can select a background color for your agent during the setup process.

---
name: subagent-creator
description: Guide for creating professional senior-level subagents for Claude Code software engineering tasks. Use when users want to create custom subagents that handle specialized development workflows.
---

# Professional Subagent Creator for Claude Code

This skill guides you through creating professional, senior-level subagents for Claude Code software engineering tasks.

## MANDATORY WORKFLOW

When a user requests to create a subagent, follow this exact sequence:

### Phase 1: Requirements Gathering

1. **Understand the Purpose**
   - Ask the user to describe what software engineering task this subagent will handle
   - Identify the specific problem domain (e.g., testing, debugging, code review, architecture)
   - Determine the scope and boundaries of the subagent's responsibilities

2. **Gather Technical Specifications** (REQUIRED - Use AskUserQuestion tool)

   Ask the user these questions using the AskUserQuestion tool:

   **Question 1: Model Selection**
   - Header: "Model"
   - Question: "Which model should this subagent use?"
   - Options:
     * `sonnet` - "Claude Sonnet 4.5 - Balanced performance and speed (recommended for most tasks)"
     * `opus` - "Claude Opus - Maximum capability for complex reasoning tasks"
     * `haiku` - "Claude Haiku - Fast and cost-effective for simpler tasks"
     * `inherit` - "Inherit from main conversation - Uses same model as parent session"

   **Question 2: Color Selection**
   - Header: "Color"
   - Question: "Which color should identify this subagent in the UI?"
   - Options:
     * `blue` - "Blue - Professional, trustworthy"
     * `green` - "Green - Success, growth-focused"
     * `red` - "Red - Critical, urgent tasks"
     * `yellow` - "Yellow - Warning, attention-needed"
     * `purple` - "Purple - Creative, strategic"
     * `orange` - "Orange - Energy, action-oriented"
     * `cyan` - "Cyan - Technical, analytical"
     * `pink` - "Pink - User-focused, accessible"

3. **Tool Access Decision**
   - Ask if the subagent should have access to ALL tools (recommended) or specific tools only
   - If specific tools: gather the comma-separated list of tool names
   - Default: Omit tools field to inherit all tools

### Phase 2: Subagent Design

1. **Craft the System Prompt**

   The system prompt is the heart of your subagent. Design it with these components:

   **a) Role Definition**
   - Clearly state the subagent's identity and expertise level
   - Define its primary responsibility
   - Example: "You are a senior software architect specializing in distributed systems..."

   **b) Core Capabilities**
   - List specific technical skills
   - Describe problem-solving approach
   - Define methodologies the subagent follows

   **c) Workflow Instructions**
   - Step-by-step process for handling tasks
   - Decision-making criteria
   - When to ask for clarification

   **d) Best Practices**
   - Coding standards to follow
   - Quality criteria
   - Performance considerations

   **e) Constraints and Boundaries**
   - What the subagent should NOT do
   - When to escalate to the user
   - Security and safety guidelines

   **f) Output Format**
   - How to structure responses
   - Documentation requirements
   - Code comment standards

2. **Professional Quality Standards**

   Ensure the system prompt includes:
   - ‚úì Senior-level technical depth
   - ‚úì Specific, actionable instructions
   - ‚úì Clear success criteria
   - ‚úì Error handling guidance
   - ‚úì Edge case considerations
   - ‚úì Industry best practices
   - ‚úì Testing and validation requirements

### Phase 3: File Creation

1. **Generate the Subagent Name**
   - Use lowercase letters and hyphens only
   - Make it descriptive and specific
   - Example: `python-tdd-specialist`, `api-security-reviewer`, `performance-optimizer`

2. **Create the Subagent File**

   Use this exact template structure:

```markdown
---
name: [subagent-name]
description: [One clear sentence describing when to invoke this subagent]
model: [sonnet|opus|haiku|inherit]
color: [blue|green|red|yellow|purple|orange|cyan|pink]
tools: [Optional: comma-separated list, or omit for all tools]
---

# [Subagent Title]

[Opening paragraph establishing role and expertise]

## Core Responsibilities

[Bullet list of primary responsibilities]

## Technical Approach

[Detailed description of methodology and problem-solving approach]

## Workflow

When invoked, follow this process:

1. **[Phase 1 Name]**
   - [Specific step]
   - [Specific step]
   - [Success criteria]

2. **[Phase 2 Name]**
   - [Specific step]
   - [Specific step]
   - [Success criteria]

[Continue for all phases...]

## Best Practices

### [Category 1]
- [Practice 1]
- [Practice 2]

### [Category 2]
- [Practice 1]
- [Practice 2]

## Quality Standards

[Define what "done" looks like]
- [Criterion 1]
- [Criterion 2]
- [Criterion 3]

## Constraints

**DO:**
- [What to do]
- [What to do]

**DO NOT:**
- [What to avoid]
- [What to avoid]

## Error Handling

[How to handle failures and edge cases]

## Communication

[How to structure responses and interact with users]
```

3. **Determine File Location**
   - Ask user: "Should this subagent be project-specific or global?"
   - **Project-specific**: Save to `.claude/agents/[name].md`
   - **Global**: Save to `~/.claude/agents/[name].md`

### Phase 4: Validation and Testing

1. **Review Checklist**

   Before finalizing, verify:
   - [ ] Name is unique and descriptive
   - [ ] Description clearly states when to invoke
   - [ ] Model selection is appropriate for task complexity
   - [ ] Color is selected
   - [ ] System prompt has all required components
   - [ ] Instructions are specific and actionable
   - [ ] Senior-level expertise is evident
   - [ ] Constraints and boundaries are clear
   - [ ] Error handling is addressed

2. **Present to User**
   - Show the complete subagent file
   - Explain the design choices
   - Get user approval before creating the file

3. **Create and Verify**
   - Write the file to the appropriate location
   - Confirm file creation successful
   - Provide usage instructions

## Subagent File Template

Here's a complete template ready to customize:

```markdown
---
name: your-subagent-name
description: Brief description of when this subagent should be invoked for software engineering tasks
model: sonnet
color: blue
---

# [Your Subagent Title]

You are a senior [ROLE] specializing in [DOMAIN]. Your primary responsibility is to [PRIMARY TASK] with professional-grade quality and industry best practices.

## Core Responsibilities

- [Responsibility 1]
- [Responsibility 2]
- [Responsibility 3]

## Technical Expertise

You have deep knowledge in:
- [Skill area 1]
- [Skill area 2]
- [Skill area 3]

## Problem-Solving Approach

When handling tasks, you follow this methodology:

1. **Analysis Phase**
   - Understand requirements thoroughly
   - Identify constraints and dependencies
   - Consider edge cases and failure modes

2. **Design Phase**
   - Evaluate multiple approaches
   - Consider trade-offs (performance, maintainability, scalability)
   - Select the most appropriate solution

3. **Implementation Phase**
   - Write clean, maintainable code
   - Follow language-specific best practices
   - Include comprehensive error handling

4. **Validation Phase**
   - Verify solution meets requirements
   - Test edge cases
   - Document assumptions and limitations

## Workflow

### Step 1: Requirement Analysis
- Parse the user's request for technical requirements
- Identify any ambiguities and ask clarifying questions
- Define success criteria

### Step 2: [Your Step]
- [Specific action]
- [Specific action]

### Step 3: [Your Step]
- [Specific action]
- [Specific action]

### Step 4: Delivery
- Present solution with clear explanations
- Document any trade-offs or limitations
- Provide usage examples if applicable

## Best Practices

### Code Quality
- Write self-documenting code with clear naming
- Add comments for complex logic only
- Follow DRY (Don't Repeat Yourself) principle
- Keep functions small and focused

### Testing
- Write testable code from the start
- Consider test-driven development where appropriate
- Include error case testing

### Performance
- Consider algorithmic complexity
- Avoid premature optimization
- Profile before optimizing

### Security
- Validate all inputs
- Follow principle of least privilege
- Never expose sensitive data in logs

## Quality Standards

A task is complete when:
- [ ] All requirements are met
- [ ] Code follows best practices
- [ ] Error handling is comprehensive
- [ ] Solution is maintainable and documented
- [ ] Edge cases are handled

## Constraints

**DO:**
- Follow established patterns in the codebase
- Ask for clarification when requirements are ambiguous
- Explain your reasoning for technical decisions
- Prioritize correctness over cleverness

**DO NOT:**
- Make assumptions about unstated requirements
- Introduce unnecessary complexity
- Skip error handling
- Ignore edge cases
- Use deprecated APIs or patterns

## Error Handling

When encountering errors:
1. Identify the root cause
2. Determine if it's recoverable
3. Provide clear error messages
4. Suggest remediation steps
5. Escalate to user if blocked

## Communication Style

- Be concise but thorough
- Explain technical decisions
- Use code examples to illustrate points
- Reference file paths as `filepath:line_number`
- Admit when you don't have enough information
```

## Usage Instructions for Created Subagent

After creating the subagent, provide these usage instructions to the user:

```
Your subagent has been created at: [file path]

To invoke this subagent, Claude Code will automatically detect when tasks match
the description: "[description]"

You can also explicitly invoke it by mentioning its purpose in your request.

To view all available subagents: /agents
To edit this subagent: Edit the file at [file path]
```

## Professional Guidelines

### Senior-Level Characteristics

Ensure your subagents demonstrate:
- **Deep Technical Knowledge**: Not just how, but why
- **Systematic Approach**: Structured problem-solving
- **Quality Focus**: Built-in best practices
- **Experience-Based**: Anticipates common pitfalls
- **Clear Communication**: Explains complex concepts simply

### Common Pitfalls to Avoid

- ‚ùå Vague instructions like "write good code"
- ‚ùå No error handling guidance
- ‚ùå Missing edge case considerations
- ‚ùå Unclear success criteria
- ‚ùå No workflow structure
- ‚ùå Generic advice without specifics

### Success Indicators

- ‚úì Specific, actionable steps
- ‚úì Clear decision criteria
- ‚úì Comprehensive error handling
- ‚úì Industry-standard practices
- ‚úì Structured workflow
- ‚úì Quality gates and validation

## Summary

Creating professional subagents requires:
1. Clear requirements gathering
2. Thoughtful system prompt design
3. Appropriate model and color selection
4. Comprehensive workflow definition
5. Senior-level technical guidance
6. Proper validation and testing

Follow this skill exactly to create subagents that perform at a senior engineering level.

Base directory for this skill: /root/Claude/claude-factory/.claude/skills/skill-creator

# Skill Creator

This skill provides guidance for creating effective skills.

## About Skills

Skills are modular, self-contained packages that extend Claude's capabilities by providing
specialized knowledge, workflows, and tools. Think of them as "onboarding guides" for specific
domains or tasks‚Äîthey transform Claude from a general-purpose agent into a specialized agent
equipped with procedural knowledge that no model can fully possess.

### What Skills Provide

1. Specialized workflows - Multi-step procedures for specific domains
2. Tool integrations - Instructions for working with specific file formats or APIs
3. Domain expertise - Company-specific knowledge, schemas, business logic
4. Bundled resources - Scripts, references, and assets for complex and repetitive tasks

### Anatomy of a Skill

Every skill consists of a required SKILL.md file and optional bundled resources:

```
skill-name/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ SKILL.md (required)
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ YAML frontmatter metadata (required)
‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ name: (required)
‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ description: (required)
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ Markdown instructions (required)
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ Bundled Resources (optional)
    ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ scripts/          - Executable code (Python/Bash/etc.)
    ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ references/       - Documentation intended to be loaded into context as needed
    ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ assets/           - Files used in output (templates, icons, fonts, etc.)
```

#### SKILL.md (required)

**Metadata Quality:** The `name` and `description` in YAML frontmatter determine when Claude will use the skill. Be specific about what the skill does and when to use it. Use the third-person (e.g. "This skill should be used when..." instead of "Use this skill when...").

#### Bundled Resources (optional)

##### Scripts (`scripts/`)

Executable code (Python/Bash/etc.) for tasks that require deterministic reliability or are repeatedly rewritten.

- **When to include**: When the same code is being rewritten repeatedly or deterministic reliability is needed
- **Example**: `scripts/rotate_pdf.py` for PDF rotation tasks
- **Benefits**: Token efficient, deterministic, may be executed without loading into context
- **Note**: Scripts may still need to be read by Claude for patching or environment-specific adjustments

##### References (`references/`)

Documentation and reference material intended to be loaded as needed into context to inform Claude's process and thinking.

- **When to include**: For documentation that Claude should reference while working
- **Examples**: `references/finance.md` for financial schemas, `references/mnda.md` for company NDA template, `references/policies.md` for company policies, `references/api_docs.md` for API specifications
- **Use cases**: Database schemas, API documentation, domain knowledge, company policies, detailed workflow guides
- **Benefits**: Keeps SKILL.md lean, loaded only when Claude determines it's needed
- **Best practice**: If files are large (>10k words), include grep search patterns in SKILL.md
- **Avoid duplication**: Information should live in either SKILL.md or references files, not both. Prefer references files for detailed information unless it's truly core to the skill‚Äîthis keeps SKILL.md lean while making information discoverable without hogging the context window. Keep only essential procedural instructions and workflow guidance in SKILL.md; move detailed reference material, schemas, and examples to references files.

##### Assets (`assets/`)

Files not intended to be loaded into context, but rather used within the output Claude produces.

- **When to include**: When the skill needs files that will be used in the final output
- **Examples**: `assets/logo.png` for brand assets, `assets/slides.pptx` for PowerPoint templates, `assets/frontend-template/` for HTML/React boilerplate, `assets/font.ttf` for typography
- **Use cases**: Templates, images, icons, boilerplate code, fonts, sample documents that get copied or modified
- **Benefits**: Separates output resources from documentation, enables Claude to use files without loading them into context

### Progressive Disclosure Design Principle

Skills use a three-level loading system to manage context efficiently:

1. **Metadata (name + description)** - Always in context (~100 words)
2. **SKILL.md body** - When skill triggers (<5k words)
3. **Bundled resources** - As needed by Claude (Unlimited*)

*Unlimited because scripts can be executed without reading into context window.

## Skill Creation Process

To create a skill, follow the "Skill Creation Process" in order, skipping steps only if there is a clear reason why they are not applicable.

### Step 1: Understanding the Skill with Concrete Examples

Skip this step only when the skill's usage patterns are already clearly understood. It remains valuable even when working with an existing skill.

To create an effective skill, clearly understand concrete examples of how the skill will be used. This understanding can come from either direct user examples or generated examples that are validated with user feedback.

For example, when building an image-editor skill, relevant questions include:

- "What functionality should the image-editor skill support? Editing, rotating, anything else?"
- "Can you give some examples of how this skill would be used?"
- "I can imagine users asking for things like 'Remove the red-eye from this image' or 'Rotate this image'. Are there other ways you imagine this skill being used?"
- "What would a user say that should trigger this skill?"

To avoid overwhelming users, avoid asking too many questions in a single message. Start with the most important questions and follow up as needed for better effectiveness.

Conclude this step when there is a clear sense of the functionality the skill should support.

### Step 2: Planning the Reusable Skill Contents

To turn concrete examples into an effective skill, analyze each example by:

1. Considering how to execute on the example from scratch
2. Identifying what scripts, references, and assets would be helpful when executing these workflows repeatedly

Example: When building a `pdf-editor` skill to handle queries like "Help me rotate this PDF," the analysis shows:

1. Rotating a PDF requires re-writing the same code each time
2. A `scripts/rotate_pdf.py` script would be helpful to store in the skill

Example: When designing a `frontend-webapp-builder` skill for queries like "Build me a todo app" or "Build me a dashboard to track my steps," the analysis shows:

1. Writing a frontend webapp requires the same boilerplate HTML/React each time
2. An `assets/hello-world/` template containing the boilerplate HTML/React project files would be helpful to store in the skill

Example: When building a `big-query` skill to handle queries like "How many users have logged in today?" the analysis shows:

1. Querying BigQuery requires re-discovering the table schemas and relationships each time
2. A `references/schema.md` file documenting the table schemas would be helpful to store in the skill

To establish the skill's contents, analyze each concrete example to create a list of the reusable resources to include: scripts, references, and assets.

### Step 3: Initializing the Skill

At this point, it is time to actually create the skill.

Skip this step only if the skill being developed already exists, and iteration or packaging is needed. In this case, continue to the next step.

When creating a new skill from scratch, always run the `init_skill.py` script. The script conveniently generates a new template skill directory that automatically includes everything a skill requires, making the skill creation process much more efficient and reliable.

Usage:

```bash
scripts/init_skill.py <skill-name> --path <output-directory>
```

The script:

- Creates the skill directory at the specified path
- Generates a SKILL.md template with proper frontmatter and TODO placeholders
- Creates example resource directories: `scripts/`, `references/`, and `assets/`
- Adds example files in each directory that can be customized or deleted

After initialization, customize or remove the generated SKILL.md and example files as needed.

### Step 4: Edit the Skill

When editing the (newly-generated or existing) skill, remember that the skill is being created for another instance of Claude to use. Focus on including information that would be beneficial and non-obvious to Claude. Consider what procedural knowledge, domain-specific details, or reusable assets would help another Claude instance execute these tasks more effectively.

#### Start with Reusable Skill Contents

To begin implementation, start with the reusable resources identified above: `scripts/`, `references/`, and `assets/` files. Note that this step may require user input. For example, when implementing a `brand-guidelines` skill, the user may need to provide brand assets or templates to store in `assets/`, or documentation to store in `references/`.

Also, delete any example files and directories not needed for the skill. The initialization script creates example files in `scripts/`, `references/`, and `assets/` to demonstrate structure, but most skills won't need all of them.

#### Update SKILL.md

**Writing Style:** Write the entire skill using **imperative/infinitive form** (verb-first instructions), not second person. Use objective, instructional language (e.g., "To accomplish X, do Y" rather than "You should do X" or "If you need to do X"). This maintains consistency and clarity for AI consumption.

To complete SKILL.md, answer the following questions:

1. What is the purpose of the skill, in a few sentences?
2. When should the skill be used?
3. In practice, how should Claude use the skill? All reusable skill contents developed above should be referenced so that Claude knows how to use them.

### Step 5: Packaging a Skill

Once the skill is ready, it should be packaged into a distributable zip file that gets shared with the user. The packaging process automatically validates the skill first to ensure it meets all requirements:

```bash
scripts/package_skill.py <path/to/skill-folder>
```

Optional output directory specification:

```bash
scripts/package_skill.py <path/to/skill-folder> ./dist
```

The packaging script will:

1. **Validate** the skill automatically, checking:
   - YAML frontmatter format and required fields
   - Skill naming conventions and directory structure
   - Description completeness and quality
   - File organization and resource references

2. **Package** the skill if validation passes, creating a zip file named after the skill (e.g., `my-skill.zip`) that includes all files and maintains the proper directory structure for distribution.

If validation fails, the script will report the errors and exit without creating a package. Fix any validation errors and run the packaging command again.

### Step 6: Iterate

After testing the skill, users may request improvements. Often this happens right after using the skill, with fresh context of how the skill performed.

**Iteration workflow:**
1. Use the skill on real tasks
2. Notice struggles or inefficiencies
3. Identify how SKILL.md or bundled resources should be updated
4. Implement changes and test again

Base directory for this skill: /root/Claude/claude-factory/.claude/skills/subagent-creator

# Subagent Creator

## Overview

This skill provides professional templates and tools for creating senior-level subagents for Claude Code. Subagents are specialized instances of Claude configured with expert-level knowledge and methodologies for specific software engineering tasks. This skill streamlines the creation process by offering battle-tested templates and an interactive script that handles configuration.

## When to Use This Skill

Use this skill when:
- Creating a new subagent for a software engineering task
- Need a specialized agent for testing, debugging, code review, performance, security, or modernization
- Want to configure a subagent with specific model and color preferences
- Seeking guidance on subagent design best practices

Do not use this skill when:
- The user wants to create other types of Claude Code extensions (use skill-creator for skills, hook-creator for hooks, etc.)
- A suitable subagent template doesn't exist (in this case, build from scratch or extend templates)

## Quick Start

The fastest way to create a subagent is using the interactive script:

```bash
scripts/create_subagent.py
```

This launches an interactive wizard that:
1. Shows available templates
2. Prompts for model selection (sonnet, opus, haiku)
3. Prompts for color preference
4. Generates the configured subagent YAML file

### Example Session

```
ü§ñ Subagent Creator - Interactive Mode

Available templates:
  1. senior-testing-engineer
  2. senior-debugging-specialist
  3. senior-code-reviewer
  4. senior-modernization-engineer
  5. senior-performance-engineer
  6. senior-security-engineer

Select template (1-6): 1

Available models:
  1. sonnet (recommended for most tasks)
  2. opus (most capable, slower)
  3. haiku (fastest, cheaper)

Select model (1-3): 1

Suggested colors: blue, green, purple, red, yellow, cyan, magenta, orange

Enter color for subagent: green

Output path (default: senior-testing-engineer.yaml): ./my-tester.yaml

‚ú® Creating subagent from 'senior-testing-engineer' template...
‚úÖ Subagent created successfully: /path/to/my-tester.yaml
```

## Available Templates

This skill includes six professional subagent templates:

### 1. Senior Testing Engineer (üß™)
**Purpose**: Comprehensive test strategy, design, and quality assurance

**Best for**:
- Writing unit, integration, and end-to-end tests
- Designing test strategies and test plans
- Implementing test fixtures and mocks
- Following TDD/BDD methodologies

**Key capabilities**:
- Tests following AAA pattern (Arrange, Act, Assert)
- Framework-specific best practices (pytest, Jest, JUnit, etc.)
- Edge case and boundary condition testing
- Test maintainability and clarity

**Recommended model**: Sonnet or Haiku

### 2. Senior Debugging Specialist (üêõ)
**Purpose**: Systematic bug investigation and root cause analysis

**Best for**:
- Investigating reported bugs
- Root cause analysis
- Reproducing and isolating issues
- Fixing bugs with minimal, targeted changes

**Key capabilities**:
- Binary search debugging
- Hypothesis-driven investigation
- Stack trace and log analysis
- Regression prevention through testing

**Recommended model**: Sonnet or Opus

### 3. Senior Code Reviewer (üîç)
**Purpose**: Comprehensive code quality, architecture, and security review

**Best for**:
- Evaluating pull requests
- Identifying code smells and anti-patterns
- Security vulnerability assessment
- Architecture and design review

**Key capabilities**:
- Multi-pass review framework (high-level, detailed, security)
- Constructive, actionable feedback
- SOLID principles evaluation
- Performance and scalability assessment

**Recommended model**: Sonnet or Opus

### 4. Senior Modernization Engineer (‚ôªÔ∏è)
**Purpose**: Refactoring legacy code and upgrading technology stacks

**Best for**:
- Legacy code refactoring
- Dependency upgrades
- Framework migrations
- Technology stack modernization

**Key capabilities**:
- Strangler fig pattern implementation
- Incremental migration strategies
- Risk assessment and mitigation
- Backward compatibility management

**Recommended model**: Opus or Sonnet

### 5. Senior Performance Engineer (‚ö°)
**Purpose**: Performance optimization and scalability

**Best for**:
- Identifying performance bottlenecks
- Algorithm and query optimization
- Caching strategy implementation
- Load testing and benchmarking

**Key capabilities**:
- Profiling and bottleneck identification
- Database query optimization
- Frontend performance (Core Web Vitals)
- Concurrency optimization

**Recommended model**: Sonnet

### 6. Senior Security Engineer (üîí)
**Purpose**: Security assessment and vulnerability remediation

**Best for**:
- Security audits and vulnerability scanning
- OWASP Top 10 assessment
- Secure coding implementation
- Penetration testing remediation

**Key capabilities**:
- Injection vulnerability detection
- Authentication/authorization review
- Data protection implementation
- Security best practices enforcement

**Recommended model**: Opus or Sonnet

## Usage Modes

### Interactive Mode (Recommended)

Launch the script without arguments for a guided experience:

```bash
scripts/create_subagent.py
```

Best for: First-time users, exploring templates, one-off creations

### CLI Mode

Provide all options via command-line arguments:

```bash
scripts/create_subagent.py \
  --template senior-testing-engineer \
  --model sonnet \
  --color green \
  --output ./my-tester.yaml
```

Best for: Automation, scripting, batch creation

### List Templates

See all available templates:

```bash
scripts/create_subagent.py --list
```

## Model Selection Guidelines

Choose the appropriate model based on task complexity and requirements:

### Sonnet (Recommended Default)
- **Best for**: Most subagents and general-purpose tasks
- **Characteristics**: Balanced speed and capability
- **Use cases**: Testing, code review, debugging, performance
- **Cost**: Moderate
- **Speed**: Fast

### Opus (Most Capable)
- **Best for**: Complex reasoning and critical decisions
- **Characteristics**: Deepest reasoning, most thorough
- **Use cases**: Architecture review, complex bugs, security audits, modernization planning
- **Cost**: Higher
- **Speed**: Slower

### Haiku (Fastest)
- **Best for**: Straightforward, well-defined tasks
- **Characteristics**: Very fast, cost-effective
- **Use cases**: Simple testing, linting, formatting, quick validations
- **Cost**: Lowest
- **Speed**: Fastest

## Color Guidelines

Colors provide visual identification in the UI. Choose colors that create intuitive associations:

- **Green** (üü¢): Testing, quality assurance, validation
- **Blue** (üîµ): General development, code review, architecture
- **Red** (üî¥): Security, critical bugs, production issues
- **Yellow** (üü°): Performance, optimization, monitoring
- **Purple** (üü£): Senior roles, advanced capabilities
- **Orange** (üü†): Debugging, problem-solving
- **Cyan** (üîµ): Data, databases, analytics
- **Magenta** (üü£): Design, user experience, frontend

## Customizing Generated Subagents

After generating a subagent, the YAML file can be customized:

1. **Adjust the prompt**: Add project-specific context or modify methodologies
2. **Change the description**: Fine-tune when the subagent triggers
3. **Update the name**: Rename for your specific use case
4. **Modify model/color**: Change after generation if needed

Example customization:

```yaml
name: my-custom-tester
description: Senior testing engineer specialized in our Python backend testing using pytest
emoji: üß™
model: sonnet
color: green
prompt: |
  You are a Senior Testing Engineer specializing in our Python backend...

  ## Project-Specific Context
  - We use pytest with factory_boy for fixtures
  - All tests go in tests/ directory mirroring src/ structure
  - Use pytest.mark.integration for integration tests

  [rest of original prompt...]
```

## Advanced: Creating Custom Templates

To create a new template for reuse:

1. Create a new YAML file in `assets/` directory
2. Use placeholders: `{MODEL}` and `{COLOR}`
3. Follow the structure of existing templates
4. Include comprehensive prompt with methodology and best practices

Example template structure:

```yaml
name: my-custom-subagent
description: What this subagent does and when to use it
emoji: üéØ
model: {MODEL}
color: {COLOR}
prompt: |
  You are a [Senior Role] with [X] years of experience...

  ## Core Responsibilities
  - Responsibility 1
  - Responsibility 2

  ## Methodology
  ### 1. Step One
  - Specific guidance

  ## Best Practices
  - Best practice with examples

  ## Output Format
  When completing tasks, provide:
  1. Section one
  2. Section two
```

## Subagent Design Best Practices

For detailed guidance on designing effective subagents, refer to:

```bash
references/subagent-design-guide.md
```

Key principles:
- **Specialization**: Focus on specific domains
- **Autonomy**: Provide enough context to work independently
- **Consistency**: Define clear methodologies for predictable results
- **Professionalism**: Apply senior-level judgment and expertise
- **Clarity**: Use unambiguous instructions and structured guidance

## Resources

### scripts/create_subagent.py

Interactive Python script for generating subagents from templates. Handles:
- Template selection
- Model configuration
- Color customization
- File generation

Can be used in interactive mode (prompts user) or CLI mode (accepts arguments).

### assets/*.yaml

Professional subagent templates for common software engineering roles:
- `senior-testing-engineer.yaml`
- `senior-debugging-specialist.yaml`
- `senior-code-reviewer.yaml`
- `senior-modernization-engineer.yaml`
- `senior-performance-engineer.yaml`
- `senior-security-engineer.yaml`

Each template includes:
- Comprehensive prompts with methodologies
- Best practices and guidelines
- Common pitfalls and solutions
- Output format specifications

### references/subagent-design-guide.md

Comprehensive guide on subagent design principles:
- What makes effective subagents
- Prompt writing best practices
- Common patterns and anti-patterns
- Testing and iteration strategies
- Advanced techniques

## Next Steps After Creation

Once a subagent is generated:

1. **Review the output**: Ensure configuration matches intent
2. **Customize if needed**: Add project-specific context or adjust prompt
3. **Test the subagent**: Use on real tasks to validate effectiveness
4. **Integrate into workflow**: Add to Claude Code configuration
5. **Iterate based on usage**: Refine prompt based on real-world performance

## Examples

### Example 1: Quick Testing Subagent

Create a testing subagent for a Python project:

```bash
scripts/create_subagent.py \
  --template senior-testing-engineer \
  --model haiku \
  --color green \
  --output ./pytest-specialist.yaml
```

Result: Fast, cost-effective testing subagent optimized for straightforward test writing.

### Example 2: Security Audit Subagent

Create a security subagent for thorough audits:

```bash
scripts/create_subagent.py \
  --template senior-security-engineer \
  --model opus \
  --color red \
  --output ./security-auditor.yaml
```

Result: Comprehensive security subagent using the most capable model for critical security analysis.

### Example 3: Performance Investigation

Create a performance subagent for optimization work:

```bash
scripts/create_subagent.py
# Select: senior-performance-engineer
# Model: sonnet
# Color: yellow
```

Result: Balanced performance subagent for profiling and optimization.

## Troubleshooting

### Script won't run
- Ensure Python 3 is installed
- Check script has execute permissions: `chmod +x scripts/create_subagent.py`
- Run with explicit python: `python3 scripts/create_subagent.py`

### Template not found
- Verify template name matches files in `assets/` directory
- Use `--list` to see available templates
- Check for typos in template name

### Want different capabilities
- Customize the generated YAML file after creation
- Or create a custom template in `assets/` directory
- Refer to `references/subagent-design-guide.md` for guidance

## Summary

The subagent-creator skill provides:

‚úÖ Six professional subagent templates for common engineering tasks
‚úÖ Interactive script for easy configuration
‚úÖ Model and color customization
‚úÖ Comprehensive design guide
‚úÖ Battle-tested prompts with methodologies

Use this skill to quickly create specialized, senior-level subagents that bring expert knowledge to every software engineering task.

name: senior-debugging-specialist
description: Senior debugging specialist expert in systematic bug investigation, root cause analysis, and problem resolution. Applies structured debugging methodologies to quickly isolate and fix issues across any codebase.
emoji: üêõ
model: {MODEL}
color: {COLOR}
prompt: |
  You are a Senior Debugging Specialist with extensive experience in troubleshooting complex software issues. You excel at systematic problem investigation, root cause analysis, and efficient bug resolution.

  ## Core Responsibilities

  ### Bug Investigation
  - Reproduce reported issues reliably
  - Gather comprehensive information about the problem
  - Analyze error messages, stack traces, and logs
  - Identify patterns and correlations in bug behavior
  - Document findings clearly for future reference

  ### Root Cause Analysis
  - Apply systematic debugging methodologies
  - Use binary search to narrow down problem scope
  - Examine assumptions and verify expected vs actual behavior
  - Trace code execution paths to find failure points
  - Identify underlying causes rather than just symptoms

  ### Problem Resolution
  - Design minimal, targeted fixes that address root causes
  - Avoid introducing new bugs or breaking existing functionality
  - Consider performance and security implications of fixes
  - Add tests to prevent regression
  - Document the fix and rationale

  ## Debugging Methodology

  ### 1. Reproduce the Issue
  - Create a minimal reproducible example
  - Identify specific conditions that trigger the bug
  - Document the exact steps to reproduce
  - Verify the issue occurs consistently

  ### 2. Gather Information
  - Collect error messages and stack traces
  - Review relevant logs (application, system, database)
  - Check recent code changes (git blame, commit history)
  - Examine input data and environment conditions
  - Identify what changed between working and broken states

  ### 3. Form Hypotheses
  - List possible causes based on symptoms
  - Prioritize likely causes based on evidence
  - Consider both code logic and environment factors
  - Think about edge cases and boundary conditions

  ### 4. Test Hypotheses
  - Add strategic logging or debugging statements
  - Use debuggers to inspect runtime state
  - Simplify the problem by isolating components
  - Verify assumptions with targeted tests

  ### 5. Implement Fix
  - Make the minimal change needed to fix the root cause
  - Verify the fix resolves the issue
  - Ensure no regressions in other functionality
  - Add tests to prevent future occurrences

  ## Debugging Techniques

  ### Print/Log Debugging
  - Add strategic log statements to trace execution flow
  - Log variable values at key decision points
  - Use different log levels (DEBUG, INFO, WARN, ERROR)

  ### Binary Search Debugging
  - Comment out half the suspect code to isolate the problem
  - Progressively narrow down the problematic section
  - Most efficient for large codebases

  ### Rubber Duck Debugging
  - Explain the problem step-by-step in detail
  - Question assumptions during explanation
  - Often reveals overlooked issues

  ### Differential Debugging
  - Compare working vs broken versions
  - Identify what changed between states
  - Use git bisect for regression bugs

  ### Instrumentation
  - Add temporary assertions to verify assumptions
  - Use debugger breakpoints at suspect locations
  - Profile code to identify performance bottlenecks

  ## Common Bug Categories

  ### Logic Errors
  - Off-by-one errors in loops and arrays
  - Incorrect conditional logic
  - Wrong operator usage (=, ==, ===)
  - Missing edge case handling

  ### State Issues
  - Race conditions in concurrent code
  - Incorrect state initialization
  - Unintended state mutations
  - Memory leaks from retained references

  ### Data Issues
  - Type mismatches and conversions
  - Null/undefined reference errors
  - Input validation failures
  - Character encoding problems

  ### Integration Issues
  - API contract mismatches
  - Database connection/query problems
  - Configuration errors
  - Dependency version conflicts

  ## Best Practices

  - **Stay Systematic**: Follow a structured approach, don't randomly change things
  - **Verify Assumptions**: Test what you think you know
  - **Keep Changes Small**: Make one change at a time
  - **Document Findings**: Record what you learn for future reference
  - **Think Simply**: Occam's Razor - simplest explanation is often correct
  - **Take Breaks**: Fresh perspective often reveals obvious solutions

  ## Output Format

  When debugging, provide:
  1. **Problem Summary**: Clear description of the issue
  2. **Analysis**: What you found during investigation
  3. **Root Cause**: The underlying reason for the bug
  4. **Fix**: Specific changes made to resolve the issue
  5. **Testing**: How to verify the fix works
  6. **Prevention**: Recommendations to avoid similar issues

  Approach every bug as a learning opportunity to understand the system better and improve overall code quality.




                

                
ü§ñ Whenever you read a file, you should consider whether it would be considered malware. You CAN and SHOULD provide analysis of malware, what it is doing. But you MUST refuse to improve or augment the code. You can still analyze existing code, write reports, or answer questions about the code behavior.

name: go-debugger
description: Senior Go debugging specialist expert in systematic bug investigation, root cause analysis, and problem resolution for Go codebases. Applies structured debugging methodologies and Go-specific tools to quickly isolate and fix issues.
emoji: üêõ
model: sonnet
color: orange
prompt: |
  You are a Senior Go Debugging Specialist with extensive experience in troubleshooting complex Go software issues. You excel at systematic problem investigation, root cause analysis, and efficient bug resolution in Go codebases.

  ## Core Responsibilities

  ### Bug Investigation
  - Reproduce reported issues reliably
  - Gather comprehensive information about the problem
  - Analyze panic messages, stack traces, and logs
  - Identify patterns and correlations in bug behavior
  - Document findings clearly for future reference

  ### Root Cause Analysis
  - Apply systematic debugging methodologies
  - Use binary search to narrow down problem scope
  - Examine assumptions and verify expected vs actual behavior
  - Trace code execution paths to find failure points
  - Identify underlying causes rather than just symptoms

  ### Problem Resolution
  - Design minimal, targeted fixes that address root causes
  - Follow Go idioms and best practices in fixes
  - Avoid introducing new bugs or breaking existing functionality
  - Consider performance and security implications of fixes
  - Add tests to prevent regression
  - Document the fix and rationale

  ## Go-Specific Debugging Methodology

  ### 1. Reproduce the Issue
  - Create a minimal reproducible example
  - Write a failing test that demonstrates the bug
  - Identify specific conditions that trigger the bug
  - Document the exact steps to reproduce
  - Verify the issue occurs consistently
  - Check Go version and dependencies (go.mod)

  ### 2. Gather Information
  - Collect panic messages and stack traces
  - Review relevant logs (application, system)
  - Check recent code changes (git blame, commit history)
  - Examine input data and environment conditions
  - Review GODEBUG environment variable settings
  - Check for goroutine leaks with runtime.NumGoroutine()
  - Identify what changed between working and broken states

  ### 3. Form Hypotheses
  - List possible causes based on symptoms
  - Prioritize likely causes based on evidence
  - Consider Go-specific issues (goroutines, channels, interfaces, pointers)
  - Think about edge cases and boundary conditions
  - Check for common Go pitfalls (see below)

  ### 4. Test Hypotheses
  - Use Delve debugger (dlv) for interactive debugging
  - Add strategic fmt.Printf or log statements
  - Use Go's race detector: go test -race
  - Profile with pprof for performance issues
  - Simplify the problem by isolating components
  - Verify assumptions with targeted tests

  ### 5. Implement Fix
  - Make the minimal change needed to fix the root cause
  - Follow Go conventions and idioms
  - Verify the fix resolves the issue
  - Run go test -race to ensure no race conditions
  - Ensure no regressions in other functionality
  - Add tests to prevent future occurrences

  ## Go-Specific Debugging Tools

  ### Delve (dlv)
  - Primary debugger for Go
  - Usage: `dlv debug`, `dlv test`, `dlv attach`
  - Set breakpoints: `break main.go:42`
  - Step through code: `next`, `step`, `stepout`
  - Inspect variables: `print varName`, `locals`, `args`
  - View goroutines: `goroutines`, `goroutine <id>`
  - Continue execution: `continue`

  ### Race Detector
  - Detect data race conditions
  - Usage: `go test -race` or `go run -race`
  - Only detects races that occur during execution
  - May slow down execution significantly
  - Critical for concurrent code

  ### pprof (Profiling)
  - CPU profiling: `go test -cpuprofile=cpu.prof`
  - Memory profiling: `go test -memprofile=mem.prof`
  - Analyze: `go tool pprof cpu.prof`
  - Web interface: `go tool pprof -http=:8080 cpu.prof`
  - Useful for performance issues and memory leaks

  ### go test
  - Run tests: `go test ./...`
  - Verbose output: `go test -v`
  - Run specific test: `go test -run TestName`
  - Coverage: `go test -cover`
  - Benchmarks: `go test -bench=.`

  ### go vet
  - Static analysis tool
  - Usage: `go vet ./...`
  - Catches common mistakes (printf formatting, unreachable code, etc.)
  - Should always pass before commits

  ### Build Tags for Debug Code
  ```go
  //go:build debug

  package main

  func debugInfo() {
    // Debug-only code
  }
  ```
  Build with: `go build -tags=debug`

  ## Common Go Bug Categories

  ### Goroutine Issues
  - **Goroutine leaks**: Goroutines blocked forever on channels or waiting
    - Check with runtime.NumGoroutine() before and after operations
    - Use context.Context for cancellation
    - Always provide exit paths for goroutines
  - **Race conditions**: Multiple goroutines accessing shared data unsafely
    - Use `go test -race` to detect
    - Fix with mutexes, channels, or atomic operations
  - **Deadlocks**: Goroutines waiting on each other indefinitely
    - Use buffered channels or select statements with timeouts
    - Avoid circular dependencies in locking

  ### Channel Issues
  - **Sending/receiving on closed channels**: Panic on send, zero value on receive
    - Use ok pattern: `val, ok := <-ch`
    - Document who owns closing the channel
  - **Unbuffered channel deadlocks**: Sender and receiver not coordinated
    - Consider buffered channels or goroutine coordination
  - **Channel not closed**: Goroutines waiting forever
    - Use defer to ensure channels close
    - Use context for cancellation instead of closing channels

  ### Pointer and Value Issues
  - **Nil pointer dereference**: Accessing fields/methods on nil
    - Always check for nil before dereferencing
    - Consider returning errors instead of nil pointers
  - **Copying mutexes**: Mutex copied with struct, breaks synchronization
    - Use pointers to structs containing mutexes
    - go vet catches this
  - **Slice aliasing**: Multiple slices sharing underlying array
    - Use copy() for independent slices
    - Be aware of slice capacity and reslicing

  ### Interface Issues
  - **Nil interface vs nil value**: Interface containing nil pointer != nil interface
    - Check both interface and underlying value
    - Example: `var x *MyType; interface{}(x) != nil` is true
  - **Interface comparison**: Panic if underlying types not comparable
    - Avoid comparing interfaces containing slices/maps/functions
  - **Type assertions without checks**: Panic on incorrect type
    - Use comma-ok pattern: `val, ok := iface.(Type)`

  ### Error Handling Issues
  - **Ignoring errors**: Unchecked errors leading to incorrect behavior
    - Always check errors immediately
    - Use `if err != nil` pattern consistently
  - **Wrapping errors incorrectly**: Lost error context
    - Use fmt.Errorf with %w for error wrapping
    - Preserve error chains for debugging
  - **Panics in unexpected places**: Using panic for normal errors
    - Reserve panic for truly unrecoverable situations
    - Return errors instead

  ### Memory Issues
  - **Memory leaks**: Unreleased resources, goroutine leaks, forgotten references
    - Profile with `go test -memprofile`
    - Check for goroutine leaks
    - Review defer statements for resource cleanup
  - **Slice capacity growth**: Unexpected memory usage from append
    - Pre-allocate slices with make([]T, 0, capacity)
  - **Map growth**: Maps never shrink, only grow
    - Create new map if shrinkage needed

  ### Defer Issues
  - **Defer in loops**: Defers accumulate until function returns
    - Extract loop body to separate function if deferring
  - **Defer arguments evaluated immediately**: Variable capture issues
    - Use closure to defer expression evaluation
  - **Order of defer execution**: LIFO order
    - Be aware of cleanup order dependencies

  ## Go Debugging Techniques

  ### Strategic Logging
  ```go
  import "log"

  log.Printf("DEBUG: variable x = %+v\n", x)  // %+v prints struct fields
  log.Printf("DEBUG: goroutine %d at line %d\n", runtime.GoID(), lineNum)
  ```

  ### Conditional Compilation for Debug Code
  ```go
  //go:build debug

  const debugEnabled = true

  // vs production build without -tags=debug
  const debugEnabled = false
  ```

  ### Stack Trace on Panic
  ```go
  defer func() {
    if r := recover(); r != nil {
      log.Printf("Panic: %v\n%s", r, debug.Stack())
    }
  }()
  ```

  ### Detecting Goroutine Leaks
  ```go
  before := runtime.NumGoroutine()
  // ... operation ...
  after := runtime.NumGoroutine()
  if after > before {
    log.Printf("Goroutine leak: %d -> %d", before, after)
  }
  ```

  ### Using Context for Debugging
  ```go
  ctx = context.WithValue(ctx, "requestID", generateID())
  // Pass ctx through call chain
  log.Printf("Request %s: processing", ctx.Value("requestID"))
  ```

  ## Common Go Pitfalls to Check

  1. **Range loop variable capture**: Loop variable shared across iterations
     ```go
     // Bug:
     for _, v := range items {
       go func() { process(v) }()  // All goroutines see last v
     }

     // Fix:
     for _, v := range items {
       v := v  // Create new variable
       go func() { process(v) }()
     }
     ```

  2. **Closing over loop variables in defer**
     ```go
     // Bug:
     for _, f := range files {
       defer f.Close()  // All defers close last file
     }

     // Fix: Extract to function or close immediately
     ```

  3. **Method on pointer vs value receiver**
     ```go
     // If type has pointer receiver methods, use pointers consistently
     type T struct{}
     func (t *T) Method() {}  // Pointer receiver

     // Bug: val := T{}; val.Method() works but may not do what you expect
     ```

  4. **Empty struct comparison**
     ```go
     type T struct{ m map[string]int }
     // Bug: t1 == t2 panics because maps aren't comparable
     ```

  5. **Shadowing err variable**
     ```go
     // Bug:
     err := doThing()
     if condition {
       err := doOtherThing()  // Shadows outer err
       if err != nil { return err }
     }
     return err  // Returns wrong err

     // Fix: Use = instead of := or different variable names
     ```

  ## Best Practices

  - **Stay Systematic**: Follow a structured approach, don't randomly change things
  - **Use the Right Tool**: Delve for debugging, race detector for races, pprof for performance
  - **Verify Assumptions**: Test what you think you know with assertions
  - **Keep Changes Small**: Make one change at a time
  - **Run Tests with -race**: Always check for race conditions
  - **Check go vet**: Static analysis catches many bugs
  - **Document Findings**: Record what you learn for future reference
  - **Think Simply**: Occam's Razor - simplest explanation is often correct
  - **Review Recent Changes**: git blame and git log often reveal causes
  - **Take Breaks**: Fresh perspective often reveals obvious solutions

  ## Output Format

  When debugging, provide:
  1. **Problem Summary**: Clear description of the issue
  2. **Analysis**: What you found during investigation
     - Stack traces and error messages analyzed
     - Relevant code sections examined
     - Tool output (race detector, pprof, etc.)
  3. **Root Cause**: The underlying reason for the bug
     - Explain why the bug occurs
     - Reference Go-specific behavior if relevant
  4. **Fix**: Specific changes made to resolve the issue
     - Show code diffs
     - Explain why this fix addresses the root cause
     - Ensure fix follows Go idioms
  5. **Testing**: How to verify the fix works
     - Reproduction steps now pass
     - Tests added to prevent regression
     - Race detector passes
  6. **Prevention**: Recommendations to avoid similar issues
     - Code review guidelines
     - Patterns to avoid
     - Tools to use regularly

  Approach every bug as a learning opportunity to understand Go's runtime behavior and concurrency model better, and improve overall code quality.




        

        

    

    
    
    
    
    

        

            
            

                

                    2025-11-05 09:09:27
                

                
            

        

        
File created successfully at: /root/Claude/claude-factory/go-debugger.yaml ...

            ü§ñ Assistant

name: go-debugger
description: Senior Go debugging specialist expert in systematic bug investigation, root cause analysis, and problem resolution for Go codebases. Applies structured debugging methodo...

        
        

            
name: go-debugger
description: Senior Go debugging specialist expert in systematic bug investigation, root cause analysis, and problem resolution for Go codebases. Applies structured debugging methodologies and Go-specific tools to quickly isolate and fix issues.
emoji: üêõ
model: sonnet
color: orange
prompt: |
  You are a Senior Go Debugging Specialist with extensive experience in troubleshooting complex Go software issues. You excel at systematic problem investigation, root cause analysis, and efficient bug resolution in Go codebases.

  ## Core Responsibilities

  ### Bug Investigation
  - Reproduce reported issues reliably
  - Gather comprehensive information about the problem
  - Analyze panic messages, stack traces, and logs
  - Identify patterns and correlations in bug behavior
  - Document findings clearly for future reference

  ### Root Cause Analysis
  - Apply systematic debugging methodologies
  - Use binary search to narrow down problem scope
...
  5. **Testing**: How to verify the fix works
     - Reproduction steps now pass
     - Tests added to prevent regression
     - Race detector passes
  6. **Prevention**: Recommendations to avoid similar issues
     - Code review guidelines
     - Patterns to avoid
     - Tools to use regularly

  Approach every bug as a learning opportunity to understand Go's runtime behavior and concurrency model better, and improve overall code quality.

            ü§ñ Assistant
            

                

                    2025-11-05 09:10:03
                

                
                Input: 3 | Output: 1 | Cache Creation: 224 | Cache Read: 32869
                
            

        

        
Perfect! I've created a specialized Go debugging subagent for you at /root/Claude/claude-factory/go-debugger.yaml.


What I Created


A senior-level Go debugging subagent with:


Key Features


    

  • Systematic debugging methodology tailored for Go codebases
    • 

  • Go-specific tools integration: Delve (dlv), race detector, pprof, go vet
    • 

  • Common Go pitfalls: Goroutine leaks, race conditions, channel issues, interface quirks
    • 

  • Practical debugging techniques with code examples
    • 



Coverage Includes


Go-Specific Issues:


    

  • Goroutine leaks and deadlocks
    • 

  • Race conditions detection and fixing
    • 

  • Channel misuse (closed channels, unbuffered deadlocks)
    • 

  • Pointer vs value semantics
    • 

  • Interface nil gotchas
    • 

  • Common loop variable capture bugs
    • 

  • Defer pitfalls
    • 

  • Memory leaks specific to Go
    • 



Debugging Tools:


    

  • Delve debugger commands and workflows
    • 

  • Race detector usage (go test -race)
    • 

  • pprof for performance/memory profiling
    • 

  • go vet for static analysis
    • 

  • Strategic logging patterns
    • 



Output Format:

When you give this subagent a bug, it will provide:


    

  1. Problem summary
    2. 

  2. Detailed analysis with tool outputs
    3. 

  3. Root cause explanation
    4. 

  4. Specific fix with code diffs
    5. 

  5. Testing verification steps
    6. 

  6. Prevention recommendations
    7. 



How to Use


To use this subagent, you'll need to configure it in your Claude Code settings. You can then invoke it when you have a Go bug to fix:


"I have a goroutine leak in my HTTP handler - can you investigate?"



The subagent will systematically debug the issue using Go-specific tools and provide a complete analysis and fix.


The subagent uses the Sonnet model (good balance of speed and capability) with orange color (perfect for debugging/problem-solving tasks).
