cat > /tmp/skill-summary.txt << 'EOF'
================================================================================
CLEAN CODE WITH DESIGN PATTERNS - SENIOR-LEVEL SKILL
================================================================================

PROJECT COMPLETION SUMMARY
================================================================================

Skill Created: clean-code-design-patterns
Package Size: 26 KB (83.5 KB uncompressed)
Location: /root/Claude/claude-factory/skills/clean-code-design-patterns.zip

================================================================================
SKILL CONTENTS
================================================================================

1. SKILL.md (9.2 KB)
   - Complete skill documentation and workflow
   - 4-phase implementation approach (Analysis ‚Üí Design ‚Üí Implementation ‚Üí Review)
   - Core clean code principles
   - Design pattern categories (Structural, Behavioral, Creational, Architectural)
   - Language-specific considerations
   - Common pitfalls and best practices
   - Practical implementation guidance

2. REFERENCES (58.4 KB total)

   a) design_patterns_guide.md (21 KB)
      - Comprehensive pattern catalog
      - Factory, Builder, Dependency Injection patterns
      - Adapter, Decorator, Facade patterns
      - Strategy, Observer, Template Method patterns
      - Repository Pattern for data access
      - Pattern selection framework
      - Anti-patterns to avoid
      - Implementation examples in Python

   b) solid_principles.md (15.3 KB)
      - Deep dive into each SOLID principle:
        * Single Responsibility Principle (SRP)
        * Open/Closed Principle (OCP)
        * Liskov Substitution Principle (LSP)
        * Interface Segregation Principle (ISP)
        * Dependency Inversion Principle (DIP)
      - Problem/solution examples for each
      - Real-world application patterns
      - Common mistakes and when NOT to apply

   c) clean_code_checklist.md (8.6 KB)
      - 100+ checklist items organized by category:
        * Naming conventions
        * Function/Method quality
        * Class/Module quality
        * Comments and documentation
        * Error handling
        * Code organization
        * Testing standards
        * SOLID principles verification
        * Performance and security
        * Language-specific checks
      - Code quality metrics
      - Quick self-review questions

   d) refactoring_strategies.md (13.3 KB)
      - Safe refactoring workflow
      - 7 core refactoring techniques:
        * Extract Method
        * Rename for Clarity
        * Remove Duplication
        * Extract Class
        * Replace Conditional with Polymorphism
        * Introduce Parameter Object
        * Replace Magic Numbers with Constants
      - Problem-driven refactoring strategies
      - When NOT to refactor
      - Measuring refactoring success

3. SCRIPTS (15.9 KB)

   code_analyzer.py
   - Automated Python code quality analysis tool
   - Detects:
     * Function complexity (cyclomatic complexity)
     * Function length violations
     * Parameter count issues
     * Class size and cohesion problems
     * Naming convention violations
     * Deep nesting patterns
     * Potential code duplication
   - Output formats: Text (human-readable) or JSON
   - Severity levels: Critical, Error, Warning, Info
   - Categories: Complexity, Design, Naming, Duplication, Syntax

================================================================================
KEY FEATURES
================================================================================

‚úì Senior-Level Guidance
  - Covers Gang of Four patterns
  - SOLID principles explained in depth
  - Real-world trade-offs discussed
  - Anti-patterns identified

‚úì Multi-Language Support
  - Language-agnostic principles
  - Language-specific idioms (Python, Java, JavaScript, Go, C#)
  - Practical examples across languages

‚úì Comprehensive Workflow
  - Analysis and Assessment phase
  - Design and Planning phase
  - Implementation phase with SOLID checks
  - Review and Refinement phase

‚úì Practical Resources
  - 100+ item quality checklist
  - 7 refactoring techniques with examples
  - Pattern selection framework
  - Code analyzer script for automation

‚úì Real-World Focus
  - Avoids over-engineering guidance
  - Context-aware pattern selection
  - Practical implementation strategies
  - When NOT to apply patterns

================================================================================
USE CASES
================================================================================

1. Implementing New Features
   ‚Üí Apply design patterns from the start
   ‚Üí Follow SOLID principles
   ‚Üí Design for testability

2. Refactoring Existing Code
   ‚Üí Identify violations systematically
   ‚Üí Apply safe refactoring techniques
   ‚Üí Improve maintainability incrementally

3. Code Review
   ‚Üí Evaluate against clean code standards
   ‚Üí Check SOLID principle adherence
   ‚Üí Identify design pattern opportunities

4. Architecture Decisions
   ‚Üí Select appropriate patterns
   ‚Üí Design abstraction layers
   ‚Üí Plan dependency management

5. Team Training
   ‚Üí Share design pattern knowledge
   ‚Üí Establish code quality standards
   ‚Üí Guide junior developers

================================================================================
FILES CREATED
================================================================================

Directory Structure:
  skills/clean-code-design-patterns/
  ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ SKILL.md
  ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ scripts/
  ‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ code_analyzer.py
  ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ references/
      ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ design_patterns_guide.md
      ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ solid_principles.md
      ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ clean_code_checklist.md
      ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ refactoring_strategies.md

Distributable Package:
  skills/clean-code-design-patterns.zip (26 KB)

================================================================================
EOF

     * Deep nesting patterns

üìö Skill Contents


1. SKILL.md - Comprehensive skill documentation featuring:


    

  • 4-phase workflow (Analysis ‚Üí Design ‚Üí Implementation ‚Üí Review)
    •

    • 

  • Design patterns by category (Structural, Behavioral, Creational, Architectural)
    • 

  • SOLID principles overview
    • 

  • Language-specific considerations
    • 

  • Common pitfalls and anti-patterns
    • 



2. Reference Guides (4 comprehensive documents):






  Reference
  Focus
  Content






  design_patterns_guide.md
  Pattern Catalog
  Factory, Builder, DI, Adapter, Decorator, Facade, Strategy, Observer, Repository patterns with full implementation examples




  solid_principles.md
  SOLID Deep Dive
  Each principle with problem/solution pairs, real-world examples, and when NOT to apply




  clean_code_checklist.md
  Quality Assurance
  100+ checklist items covering naming, functions, classes, testing, SOLID, security, and language-specific checks




  refactoring_strategies.md
  Improvement Techniques
  7 core refactoring techniques with before/after examples, safe workflows, and success metrics

  • Detects: Function complexity, class cohesion, naming violations, deep nesting, duplication
    • 

  • Outputs: Human-readable text or JSON format

  • Severity levels: Critical, Error, Warning, Info

The user wants me to create a slash command that sets up CI/CD for a project. Let me understand what this means:

1. A slash command is a custom command that can be invoked in Claude Code
2. When invo...

        
        

            
The user wants me to create a slash command that sets up CI/CD for a project. Let me understand what this means:


    

  1. A slash command is a custom command that can be invoked in Claude Code
    2. 

  2. When invoked, it should set up CI/CD for a project
    3. 

  3. According to the CLAUDE.md file, I'm in a "Claude Factory" workspace where I create tools for Claude Code
    4. 



To create a slash command, I need to:


    

  1. Create a markdown file in the .claude/commands/ directory
    2. 

  2. The slash command will expand to a prompt that can be used in Claude Code
    3. 



Let me first check what structure exists and if there are any existing slash commands to understand the pattern.


Then I'll create a comprehensive slash command that sets up CI/CD. This could include:


    

  • Setting up GitHub Actions
    • 

  • Creating workflow files
    • 

  • Configuring environment variables
    • 

  • Setting up basic CI/CD pipeline
    • 



Let me start by exploring the project structure to see if there are existing slash commands and understand the format.

# Setup CI/CD Pipeline

You are tasked with setting up a complete CI/CD pipeline for this project. Follow these steps:

## 1. Analyze the Project

# Setup CI/CD Pipeline

You are tasked with setting up a complete CI/CD pipeline for this project. Follow these steps:

## 1. Analyze the Project
- Identify the programming language and project type
- Check for existing configuration files (package.json, go.mod, requirements.txt, etc.)
- Determine if the project is a monorepo or single repository

## 2. Choose CI/CD Platform
- Recommend GitHub Actions as the default CI/CD platform (works with any git repository)
- Ask the user if they prefer a different platform (GitLab CI, CircleCI, Jenkins, etc.)

## 3. Create CI/CD Workflow
Create appropriate workflow files based on the project type:

**For Node.js projects:**
- Build and test on multiple Node versions
- Lint and format checks
- Security vulnerability scanning
- npm publish (if applicable)

**For Python projects:**
- Install dependencies and run tests
- Linting with flake8/pylint
- Type checking with mypy
- Code coverage reports

**For Go projects:**
- Build for multiple platforms
- Run tests with coverage
- Lint with golangci-lint
- Security scanning

**For other languages:**
- Apply similar principles (build, test, lint, security)

## 4. Configure Environment Variables
- Document required environment variables
- Set up secrets management
- Create example .env files (without sensitive data)

## 5. Setup Artifact Management
- Configure artifact storage for builds
- Setup test report generation
- Configure logs and metrics

## 6. Create Documentation
- Document the CI/CD setup in a CI/CD_SETUP.md file
- Explain how to trigger pipelines
- Document environment variable requirements
- Include troubleshooting steps

## 7. Implementation Steps
1. Create the necessary workflow/pipeline configuration files
2. Configure build steps appropriate for the project
3. Add testing and linting stages
4. Configure deployment stages (if applicable)
5. Set up notifications (Slack, email, etc.) if needed
6. Test the pipeline with a sample commit

## Output
Provide:
- The complete CI/CD configuration files
- Documentation of what was set up
- Instructions for team members
- Any required secrets/environment variables to configure

Perfect! I've created a slash command for setting up CI/CD. Here's what I set up:


Created: /setup-cicd Slash Command


Location: .claude/commands/setup-cicd.md


What it does:


When you invoke /setup-cicd in Claude Code, it will guide you through setting up a complete CI/CD pipeline with the following capabilities:


    

  1. Project Analysis - Identifies your project type and language
    2. 

  2. Platform Selection - Defaults to GitHub Actions but supports other platforms
    3. 

  3. Language-Specific Workflows - Generates appropriate configurations for:
      

    • Node.js (testing, linting, publishing)
      • 

    • Python (testing, type checking, coverage)
      • 

    • Go (multi-platform builds, testing)
      • 

    • Other languages (generic patterns)
      • 

    

    4. 

  4. Environment & Secrets - Sets up secure credential management
    5. 

  5. Artifact Management - Configures build artifacts and test reports
    6. 

  6. Documentation - Auto-generates CI/CD setup documentation
    7. 

  7. Testing - Validates the pipeline configuration
    8. 



How to use it:


Simply type /setup-cicd in Claude Code and it will prompt you to set up a complete CI/CD pipeline for your project.


The command is now available and ready to use!

Base directory for this skill: /root/Claude/claude-factory/.claude/skills/subagent-creator

# Subagent Creator

## Overview

This skill provides a complete framework for creating professional, senior-level subagents for Claude Code that handle software engineering tasks. Use this skill when users want to create specialized agents for testing, debugging, code review, architecture, performance optimization, security auditing, or any other software engineering domain.

The skill includes:
- Interactive questionnaire-driven agent creation
- Professional templates for common SE domains
- Validation tools to ensure quality
- Best practices and guidelines
- Reference documentation for colors, models, and domains

## When to Use This Skill

Use this skill when the user:
- Wants to create a new subagent for Claude Code
- Asks for help building a specialized agent
- Needs a debugger, tester, reviewer, or other SE-focused agent
- Mentions creating automation for specific development tasks
- Wants to customize or improve an existing subagent

**Example requests:**
- "Create a subagent for debugging Go code"
- "I need an agent that does TDD for Python"
- "Help me build a code reviewer for React apps"
- "Create a subagent that specializes in API design"

## Core Capabilities

This skill provides three main workflows:

### 1. Interactive Subagent Creation (Recommended)

Use the interactive script to guide users through creating a subagent with a questionnaire approach.

**When to use:**
- User wants to create a new subagent
- User needs guidance on what to include
- Creating from scratch or adapting templates

**How to use:**
```bash
python3 scripts/create_subagent.py
```

The script will:
1. Gather basic information (name, category, language/framework)
2. Ask about model and color preferences
3. Collect detailed requirements and scenarios
4. Select appropriate template
5. Generate complete subagent with documentation

**Output:**
- `<agent-name>/<agent-name>.md` - Complete subagent file
- `<agent-name>/metadata.json` - Creation metadata
- `<agent-name>/README.md` - Usage documentation

### 2. Subagent Validation

Validate subagent files to ensure they meet quality standards and best practices.

**When to use:**
- After creating or modifying a subagent
- Before deploying to `~/.claude/agents/`
- To check compliance with standards

**How to use:**
```bash
python3 scripts/validate_subagent.py <path-to-subagent.md>
```

The validator checks for:
- Valid YAML frontmatter format
- Required fields (name, description, color)
- Description quality (examples, trigger conditions)
- Recommended sections (methodology, tools, criteria)
- Best practices compliance

**Output:**
- Validation report with errors and warnings
- Specific line references for issues
- Recommendations for improvement

### 3. Manual Subagent Creation

For advanced users who want full control, use the templates and references directly.

**Available templates:**
- `assets/templates/generic-template.md` - Base template with placeholders
- `assets/templates/go-debugger-template.md` - Complete Go debugging specialist
- `assets/templates/python-tdd-template.md` - Complete Python TDD specialist

**How to use:**
1. Copy a template: `cp assets/templates/go-debugger-template.md my-agent.md`
2. Customize the content for your needs
3. Update frontmatter (name, description, model, color)
4. Validate: `python3 scripts/validate_subagent.py my-agent.md`
5. Deploy: `cp my-agent.md ~/.claude/agents/`

## Subagent Creation Workflow

### Step 1: Understand Requirements

Before creating a subagent, clarify:

**Purpose & Scope:**
- What specific problem does this subagent solve?
- What are the boundaries (what it should and shouldn't do)?
- Is this for a specific language, framework, or domain?

**Typical Scenarios:**
- When would a user invoke this subagent?
- What are 2-3 concrete examples of requests?
- What triggers make this agent appropriate?

**Technical Details:**
- What programming languages/frameworks are involved?
- What tools and commands will the agent use?
- What level of complexity (haiku, sonnet, or opus)?

### Step 2: Select Model and Color

**Model Selection:**

Refer to `references/available-colors-and-models.md` for details.

- **sonnet** - Default for most tasks (balanced cost/performance)
- **opus** - Complex analysis, architecture decisions, security audits
- **haiku** - Simple, fast tasks (validators, formatters)

**Color Selection:**

Choose a color that represents the agent's purpose:
- **blue** - Reviewers, architects (professional, trustworthy)
- **green** - Testers, validators (success, testing)
- **pink** - Debuggers, troubleshooters (attention, debugging)
- **purple** - Engineers, implementers (creative, technical)
- **red** - Security auditors (critical, security)
- **orange** - Performance optimizers (energy, performance)

See `references/available-colors-and-models.md` for full list.

### Step 3: Choose Creation Method

**Option A: Interactive (Recommended)**
```bash
python3 scripts/create_subagent.py
```
- Best for first-time users
- Guides through all decisions
- Generates complete agent

**Option B: Template-Based (Fast)**
```bash
# Copy template
cp assets/templates/go-debugger-template.md my-debugger.md

# Edit with your specifics
# Update name, description, model, color in frontmatter
```
- Best for experienced users
- Complete examples to adapt
- Full control over content

**Option C: From Scratch (Advanced)**
```bash
# Use generic template
cp assets/templates/generic-template.md my-agent.md

# Replace all {{PLACEHOLDERS}}
# Build methodology from scratch
```
- Maximum flexibility
- Requires understanding of best practices
- Use `references/subagent-best-practices.md` as guide

### Step 4: Customize Content

Key sections to customize:

**Frontmatter:**
```yaml
---
name: agent-name
description: Use this agent when [trigger]. Examples: [concrete examples]
model: sonnet|opus|haiku
color: blue|green|purple|etc
---
```

**Role & Expertise:**
Define who the agent is:
```markdown
You are a [role title] with [X]+ years of experience specializing in [domain].
Your expertise includes:
- [Expertise area 1]
- [Expertise area 2]
```

**Methodology:**
Structure the agent's approach into phases:
```markdown
### Phase 1: [Name]
**Purpose**: [What this phase accomplishes]
**Steps:** [Numbered, actionable steps]
**Tools:** [Which tools to use and how]
**Output**: [What this phase delivers]
```

**Tool Guidelines:**
Provide specific guidance for each tool (Read, Write, Edit, Glob, Grep, Bash).

**Quality Criteria:**
Define measurable success criteria as a checklist.

### Step 5: Add Concrete Examples

In the description field, include 2-3 examples:

```markdown
description: Use this agent when [trigger condition]. Examples:\n\n
<example>
Context: [Describe the situation]
user: "[User's request]"
assistant: "[How main Claude would invoke this agent]"
<commentary>[Why this agent is appropriate]</commentary>
</example>
```

### Step 6: Validate

Before deploying, validate the subagent:

```bash
python3 scripts/validate_subagent.py path/to/agent.md
```

Fix any errors and address warnings to improve quality.

### Step 7: Deploy

Copy the validated subagent to Claude's agents directory:

```bash
cp path/to/agent.md ~/.claude/agents/
```

Restart Claude Code or reload agents to make it available.

## Best Practices

### Description Quality
- Include 2-3 concrete examples with context
- Use `<example>`, `<commentary>` tags
- Clearly state when to use the agent
- Provide proactive invocation guidance

### Methodology Structure
- Organize into 3-5 clear phases
- Each phase has: Purpose, Steps, Tools, Output
- Steps are specific and actionable
- Tool usage is explicit (not just "use tools")

### Language/Framework Specificity
- Include language-specific patterns and idioms
- Reference common libraries and frameworks
- Account for ecosystem peculiarities
- Provide concrete code examples

### Tool Usage
- Specify exact commands and patterns
- Provide example Grep patterns: `panic\(|error|fatal`
- Show Glob patterns: `**/*_test.go`
- Include Bash commands: `go test -race ./...`

### Quality Criteria
- Use checklist format (- [ ] items)
- Make criteria measurable and specific
- Cover all aspects (functionality, quality, testing)
- Define clear success conditions

### Edge Cases
- Document 3-5 common edge cases
- Provide specific handling approaches
- Include code examples for solutions
- Cover language-specific pitfalls

## Reference Documentation

This skill includes comprehensive reference documentation:

### references/subagent-best-practices.md
Complete guide to creating effective subagents:
- Core principles (single responsibility, clarity, autonomy)
- Description field guidelines with examples
- Methodology structure patterns
- Tool usage best practices
- Language/framework specificity guidance
- Quality criteria definition
- Common pitfalls to avoid

**Use when:** Creating or improving any subagent

### references/available-colors-and-models.md
Reference for valid models and colors:
- Model descriptions and use cases
- Color psychology and recommendations
- Selection tips and guidelines

**Use when:** Choosing model or color for a subagent

### references/software-engineering-domains.md
Catalog of SE domains and specializations:
- Testing & QA (TDD, automation, validation)
- Debugging & troubleshooting (language-specific, performance)
- Architecture & design (systems, APIs, databases)
- Code quality (review, refactoring, documentation)
- Security (audits, pentesting, compliance)
- Performance & optimization
- DevOps & infrastructure
- Migration & modernization
- Domain-specific (frontend, backend, mobile, data, ML)

**Use when:** Helping users identify what type of subagent they need

## Template Reference

### Generic Template
`assets/templates/generic-template.md`

Base template with placeholders for all sections:
- {{AGENT_NAME}}, {{MODEL}}, {{COLOR}}
- {{ROLE_TITLE}}, {{SPECIALIZATION}}
- {{PHASE_N_NAME}}, {{PHASE_N_PURPOSE}}
- All standard sections included

**Use for:** Creating custom agents from scratch

### Go Debugger Template
`assets/templates/go-debugger-template.md`

Complete, production-ready Go debugging specialist:
- Panic analysis and stack trace interpretation
- Goroutine debugging and deadlock detection
- Race condition analysis
- Memory leak investigation
- Delve debugger integration
- Go-specific error patterns

**Use for:** Go debugging agents or as example of complete agent

### Python TDD Template
`assets/templates/python-tdd-template.md`

Complete, production-ready Python TDD specialist:
- Strict red-green-refactor methodology
- pytest framework integration
- Test design patterns (fixtures, mocks, parametrization)
- Coverage analysis
- Refactoring while maintaining tests
- PEP 8 compliance

**Use for:** Python TDD agents or testing-focused agents

## Common Scenarios

### Scenario 1: User Wants Go Debugger

**User request:** "Create me a subagent on a senior level for debugging go codebase"

**Approach:**
1. Use interactive creation: `python3 scripts/create_subagent.py`
2. Or use template: `cp assets/templates/go-debugger-template.md go-debugger.md`
3. Customize name, model (sonnet), color (pink)
4. Validate: `python3 scripts/validate_subagent.py go-debugger.md`
5. Deploy: `cp go-debugger.md ~/.claude/agents/`

**Result:** Ready-to-use Go debugging specialist

### Scenario 2: User Wants Python TDD Agent

**User request:** "Create me a subagent for using TDD for python codebase"

**Approach:**
1. Use template: `cp assets/templates/python-tdd-template.md python-tdd-specialist.md`
2. Customize if needed (model: sonnet, color: green)
3. Validate: `python3 scripts/validate_subagent.py python-tdd-specialist.md`
4. Deploy: `cp python-tdd-specialist.md ~/.claude/agents/`

**Result:** Ready-to-use Python TDD specialist

### Scenario 3: User Wants Custom React Reviewer

**User request:** "I need a code reviewer for React applications"

**Approach:**
1. Run interactive: `python3 scripts/create_subagent.py`
2. Answer questions:
   - Name: react-code-reviewer
   - Category: Code Reviewer
   - Language: JavaScript/TypeScript
   - Framework: React
   - Model: sonnet
   - Color: blue
   - Purpose: Review React code for quality, performance, and best practices
   - Scenarios: Component review, hooks usage, state management
3. Customize generated template for React-specific patterns
4. Add React-specific tool patterns (Grep for hooks, component patterns)
5. Validate and deploy

**Result:** Custom React code reviewer

### Scenario 4: Modifying Existing Agent

**User request:** "I have an agent but it needs improvement"

**Approach:**
1. Read existing agent: `Read ~/.claude/agents/my-agent.md`
2. Validate to identify issues: `python3 scripts/validate_subagent.py ~/.claude/agents/my-agent.md`
3. Review best practices: Point to `references/subagent-best-practices.md`
4. Edit specific sections (description, methodology, tools)
5. Re-validate after changes
6. Test with real scenarios

**Result:** Improved existing agent

## Validation and Quality Assurance

Always validate subagents before deployment:

```bash
python3 scripts/validate_subagent.py <agent-file>
```

**What validation checks:**
- ‚úÖ Valid YAML frontmatter
- ‚úÖ Required fields present (name, description, color)
- ‚úÖ Valid color from allowed list
- ‚úÖ Valid model (if specified)
- ‚úÖ Description includes examples
- ‚úÖ Description has trigger conditions
- ‚úÖ Recommended sections present
- ‚úÖ Phase-based methodology
- ‚úÖ Tool usage guidelines
- ‚úÖ DO/DO NOT lists
- ‚úÖ Success criteria defined

**Interpreting results:**
- **Errors**: Must fix before deployment
- **Warnings**: Recommendations for improvement (optional but encouraged)
- **Pass with warnings**: Agent is functional but can be improved

## Deployment

Once validated, deploy the subagent:

**Method 1: Manual Copy**
```bash
cp path/to/agent.md ~/.claude/agents/
```

**Method 2: Direct Creation in Target**
Create the agent directly in `~/.claude/agents/` directory.

**After deployment:**
- Restart Claude Code or reload agents
- Test with real scenarios
- Gather feedback
- Iterate and improve

## Iteration and Improvement

Subagents should evolve based on usage:

**After using a subagent:**
1. Note what worked well
2. Identify unclear instructions
3. Find missing edge cases
4. Recognize inefficient patterns

**To improve:**
1. Edit the subagent file
2. Add clarity to methodology
3. Expand tool usage examples
4. Add edge cases to documentation
5. Re-validate
6. Redeploy

**Version control recommended:**
Keep subagents in git to track improvements over time.

## Troubleshooting

### Issue: Validation fails with frontmatter errors

**Solution:**
- Ensure opening `---` is on line 1
- Ensure closing `---` has blank line after
- Check YAML syntax (key: value format)
- Use straight quotes, not curly quotes

### Issue: Description validation fails

**Solution:**
- Add 2-3 `<example>` blocks with concrete scenarios
- Include `<commentary>` in each example
- Add trigger phrase: "Use this agent when..."
- See `references/subagent-best-practices.md` for format

### Issue: Agent doesn't get invoked

**Solution:**
- Review description trigger conditions
- Make examples more specific to use cases
- Check that agent file is in `~/.claude/agents/`
- Restart Claude Code

### Issue: Agent produces poor results

**Solution:**
- Review methodology - is it specific enough?
- Add concrete tool usage examples
- Define clearer success criteria
- Add more edge case handling
- Consider using higher model (opus vs sonnet)

## Advanced Topics

### Creating Multi-Language Agents

For agents that work across languages:
- Use generic template as base
- Add language-specific sections
- Provide tool patterns for each language
- Include examples for each language

### Creating Specialized Frameworks Agents

For framework-specific agents (React, Django, Rails):
- Start with language template
- Add framework-specific patterns
- Include ecosystem tools and libraries
- Reference framework documentation
- Add framework-specific edge cases

### Creating Hybrid Agents

For agents with multiple responsibilities:
- Generally avoid (violates single responsibility)
- If necessary, clearly separate concerns
- Use workflow decision tree in description
- Consider splitting into multiple focused agents

## Resources Summary

**Scripts:**
- `scripts/create_subagent.py` - Interactive agent creator
- `scripts/validate_subagent.py` - Validation tool

**References:**
- `references/subagent-best-practices.md` - Comprehensive best practices
- `references/available-colors-and-models.md` - Color and model reference
- `references/software-engineering-domains.md` - SE domain catalog

**Templates:**
- `assets/templates/generic-template.md` - Base template
- `assets/templates/go-debugger-template.md` - Complete Go debugger
- `assets/templates/python-tdd-template.md` - Complete Python TDD specialist

## Quick Start Examples

**Create Go debugger:**
```bash
python3 scripts/create_subagent.py
# Follow prompts, select "Debugger", "Go", sonnet, pink
```

**Create Python TDD agent:**
```bash
cp assets/templates/python-tdd-template.md python-tdd.md
python3 scripts/validate_subagent.py python-tdd.md
cp python-tdd.md ~/.claude/agents/
```

**Validate existing agent:**
```bash
python3 scripts/validate_subagent.py ~/.claude/agents/my-agent.md
```

**Create custom agent:**
```bash
python3 scripts/create_subagent.py
# Follow prompts, provide custom details
# Edit generated file as needed
# Validate and deploy
```

#!/usr/bin/env python3
"""
Interactive script to create professional senior-level subagents for Claude Code.

This script guides users through a questionnaire to gather requirements and

#!/usr/bin/env python3
"""
Interactive script to create professional senior-level subagents for Claude Code.

This script guides users through a questionnaire to gather requirements and
generates a subagent based on templates and best practices.
"""

import os
import sys
from pathlib import Path
from datetime import datetime
import json


def print_header(text):
    """Print a formatted header."""
    print(f"\n{'='*70}")
    print(f"  {text}")
    print(f"{'='*70}\n")


def print_section(text):
    """Print a formatted section header."""
    print(f"\n{text}")
    print("-" * len(text))


def get_input(prompt, options=None, allow_custom=True):
    """
    Get user input with optional validation against a list of options.

    Args:
        prompt: The prompt to display
        options: List of valid options (or None for free text)
        allow_custom: Whether to allow custom input beyond options

    Returns:
        User's input (validated if options provided)
    """
    while True:
        if options:
            print(f"\n{prompt}")
            for i, option in enumerate(options, 1):
                print(f"  {i}. {option}")
            if allow_custom:
                print(f"  {len(options) + 1}. Custom (enter your own)")

        user_input = input(f"\n> ").strip()

        if not user_input:
            print("‚ö†Ô∏è  Input cannot be empty. Please try again.")
            continue

        if options:
            try:
                choice = int(user_input)
                if 1 <= choice <= len(options):
                    return options[choice - 1]
                elif allow_custom and choice == len(options) + 1:
                    custom = input("Enter custom value: ").strip()
                    return custom if custom else get_input(prompt, options, allow_custom)
                else:
                    print(f"‚ö†Ô∏è  Please enter a number between 1 and {len(options) + (1 if allow_custom else 0)}")
            except ValueError:
                # Not a number, treat as direct input if allowed
                if allow_custom and user_input not in options:
                    return user_input
                elif user_input in options:
                    return user_input
                else:
                    print(f"‚ö†Ô∏è  Invalid input. Please choose from the options or enter a number.")
        else:
            return user_input


def main():
    """Main entry point for the subagent creator."""
    print_header("Claude Code Subagent Creator")
    print("This tool will guide you through creating a professional senior-level subagent.")
    print("Answer the questions to generate a customized subagent for your needs.")

    # Step 1: Basic Information
    print_section("Step 1: Basic Information")

    agent_name = get_input("What is the name of your subagent? (e.g., 'go-debugger', 'python-tdd-specialist')")

    print("\nWhat type of subagent are you creating?")
    categories = [
        "Debugger (finding and fixing bugs)",
        "TDD/Testing Specialist (test-driven development)",
        "Code Reviewer (reviewing code quality)",
        "Performance Optimizer (improving performance)",
        "Security Auditor (security analysis)",
        "Refactoring Specialist (code improvement)",
        "API Designer (API design and documentation)",
        "Architect (system design and architecture)",
    ]
    category = get_input("Select a category:", categories)

    # Step 2: Language/Framework
    print_section("Step 2: Language & Framework Specificity")

    languages = ["Python", "Go", "JavaScript/TypeScript", "Java", "Rust", "C++", "Ruby", "C#"]
    primary_language = get_input("What is the primary programming language?", languages)

    frameworks = input("\nAny specific frameworks? (e.g., Django, React, gin) [press Enter to skip]: ").strip()

    # Step 3: Model Selection
    print_section("Step 3: Model Selection")

    print("\nModel capabilities:")
    print("  ‚Ä¢ sonnet - Balanced performance and cost (recommended for most tasks)")
    print("  ‚Ä¢ opus   - Highest capability for complex analysis")
    print("  ‚Ä¢ haiku  - Fast and cost-effective for simple tasks")

    models = ["sonnet", "opus", "haiku"]
    model = get_input("Which model should this subagent use?", models, allow_custom=False)

    # Step 4: Color Selection
    print_section("Step 4: Color Selection")

    print("\nAvailable colors:")
    colors = ["blue", "purple", "yellow", "pink", "green", "red", "orange", "cyan", "gray"]
    color_descriptions = {
        "blue": "Professional, trustworthy (reviewers, architects)",
        "purple": "Creative, technical (engineers, implementers)",
        "yellow": "Planning, organization (planners)",
        "pink": "Attention, debugging (debuggers, troubleshooters)",
        "green": "Success, testing (testers, validators)",
        "red": "Critical, security (security auditors)",
        "orange": "Energy, performance (optimizers)",
        "cyan": "Data, analysis (data engineers)",
        "gray": "Neutral, utility (general tools)",
    }

    for color in colors:
        print(f"  ‚Ä¢ {color:8} - {color_descriptions[color]}")

    color = get_input("\nWhich color represents this subagent best?", colors, allow_custom=False)

    # Step 5: Detailed Requirements
    print_section("Step 5: Detailed Requirements")

    print("\nDescribe the main responsibility of this subagent in 1-2 sentences:")
    main_purpose = input("> ").strip()

    print("\nWhat are 2-3 typical scenarios where this subagent would be used?")
    print("(Enter each scenario, press Enter twice when done)")
    scenarios = []
    while True:
        scenario = input(f"Scenario {len(scenarios) + 1}: ").strip()
        if not scenario:
            if scenarios:
                break
            else:
                print("Please provide at least one scenario.")
                continue
        scenarios.append(scenario)
        if len(scenarios) >= 3:
            more = input("Add another scenario? (y/n): ").strip().lower()
            if more != 'y':
                break

    # Step 6: Template Selection
    print_section("Step 6: Template Selection")

    templates_dir = Path(__file__).parent.parent / "assets" / "templates"
    available_templates = [
        ("generic", "Generic template (customizable base)"),
        ("go-debugger", "Go debugger (for Go debugging tasks)"),
        ("python-tdd", "Python TDD specialist (test-driven development)"),
    ]

    print("\nAvailable templates:")
    template_choice = get_input("Select a template to base your subagent on:", [t[1] for t in available_templates])

    # Map choice back to template name
    template_name = None
    for name, desc in available_templates:
        if desc == template_choice:
            template_name = name
            break

    # Step 7: Generate Subagent
    print_section("Step 7: Generating Subagent")

    output_dir = Path.cwd() / agent_name
    if output_dir.exists():
        overwrite = input(f"\n‚ö†Ô∏è  Directory '{agent_name}' already exists. Overwrite? (y/n): ").strip().lower()
        if overwrite != 'y':
            print("\n‚ùå Aborted.")
            return 1

    output_dir.mkdir(parents=True, exist_ok=True)

    # Load template
    if template_name == "go-debugger":
        template_file = templates_dir / "go-debugger-template.md"
    elif template_name == "python-tdd":
        template_file = templates_dir / "python-tdd-template.md"
    else:
        template_file = templates_dir / "generic-template.md"

    # Read template
    with open(template_file, 'r') as f:
        content = f.read()

    # For specific templates, update the metadata
    if template_name in ["go-debugger", "python-tdd"]:
        # These are complete templates, just update name, model, and color
        lines = content.split('\n')
        new_lines = []
        in_frontmatter = False
        frontmatter_count = 0

        for line in lines:
            if line.strip() == '---':
                frontmatter_count += 1
                in_frontmatter = frontmatter_count == 1
                new_lines.append(line)
                continue

            if in_frontmatter:
                if line.startswith('name:'):
                    new_lines.append(f'name: {agent_name}')
                elif line.startswith('model:'):
                    new_lines.append(f'model: {model}')
                elif line.startswith('color:'):
                    new_lines.append(f'color: {color}')
                else:
                    new_lines.append(line)
            else:
                new_lines.append(line)

        content = '\n'.join(new_lines)

    # Write subagent file
    output_file = output_dir / f"{agent_name}.md"
    with open(output_file, 'w') as f:
        f.write(content)

    # Create metadata file for reference
    metadata = {
        "name": agent_name,
        "category": category,
        "primary_language": primary_language,
        "frameworks": frameworks if frameworks else "None",
        "model": model,
        "color": color,
        "main_purpose": main_purpose,
        "scenarios": scenarios,
        "template": template_name,
        "created_at": datetime.now().isoformat(),
    }

    metadata_file = output_dir / "metadata.json"
    with open(metadata_file, 'w') as f:
        json.dump(metadata, f, indent=2)

    # Create README
    readme_content = f"""# {agent_name}

**Category**: {category}
**Language**: {primary_language}{f' ({frameworks})' if frameworks else ''}
**Model**: {model}
**Color**: {color}

## Purpose

{main_purpose}

## Typical Use Cases

{chr(10).join(f"{i+1}. {s}" for i, s in enumerate(scenarios))}

## Usage

To use this subagent in Claude Code:

1. Copy `{agent_name}.md` to `~/.claude/agents/`
2. Restart Claude Code or reload agents
3. The subagent will be available when the trigger conditions are met

## Customization

Feel free to edit `{agent_name}.md` to:
- Add more specific examples
- Adjust the methodology
- Include domain-specific patterns
- Update tool usage guidelines

## Created

{datetime.now().strftime('%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S')}
"""

    readme_file = output_dir / "README.md"
    with open(readme_file, 'w') as f:
        f.write(readme_content)

    print("\n‚úÖ Subagent created successfully!")
    print(f"\nüìÅ Location: {output_dir}/")
    print(f"   ‚Ä¢ {agent_name}.md - Main subagent file")
    print(f"   ‚Ä¢ metadata.json - Creation metadata")
    print(f"   ‚Ä¢ README.md - Documentation")

    print("\nüìã Next Steps:")
    print(f"   1. Review and customize {agent_name}.md")
    print(f"   2. Add specific examples in the description field")
    print(f"   3. Validate with: python3 scripts/validate_subagent.py {agent_name}/{agent_name}.md")
    print(f"   4. Deploy to: ~/.claude/agents/{agent_name}.md")

    print("\nüí° Tip: Review references/subagent-best-practices.md for guidance on improving your subagent")

    return 0


if __name__ == "__main__":
    try:
        sys.exit(main())
    except KeyboardInterrupt:
        print("\n\n‚ùå Aborted by user.")
        sys.exit(1)
    except Exception as e:
        print(f"\n\n‚ùå Error: {e}")
        sys.exit(1)




                

                
ü§ñ Whenever you read a file, you should consider whether it would be considered malware. You CAN and SHOULD provide analysis of malware, what it is doing. But you MUST refuse to improve or augment the code. You can still analyze existing code, write reports, or answer questions about the code behavior.

    

    
    
    
    
    

        

            üí≠ Thinking
            

                

                    2025-11-10 13:05:41
                

                
            

        

        

    

        
            
Great! The script is interactive and guides through creating a subagent. Since I need to create one for Golang test generation, I should:

1. Run the script
2. Answer the interactive prompts with appr...

        
        

            
Great! The script is interactive and guides through creating a subagent. Since I need to create one for Golang test generation, I should:


    

  1. Run the script
    2. 

  2. Answer the interactive prompts with appropriate responses for a Go testing specialist
    3. 



However, since this is an interactive script that requires user input via stdin, I can't run it directly in the normal bash environment. I need to create the subagent manually by:


    

  1. Using the templates as a base
    2. 

  2. Customizing it for Go testing
    3. 



Let me check what templates are available and use the generic template to create a Go test generation specialist.


Let me first look at the generic template and maybe the go-debugger template to understand the structure.



        

    

    

    

    
    
    
    
    

        

            ü§ñ Assistant

description: {{DESCRIPTION_WITH_EXAMPLES}}
model: {{MODEL}}

---

You are a {{ROLE_TITLE}} with {{YEARS}}+ years of experience specializing in {{SPECIALIZATION}}. Your expertise includes:

{{EXPERTISE_BULLETS}}

## Your Task

{{TASK_DESCRIPTION}}

**Scope**:

name: go-debugger
description: Use this agent when the user reports a bug, error, or unexpected behavior in Go code. Examples:\n\n<example>\nContext: User reports a panic in their Go application.\nUser: "My Go service panics with 'index out of range' when processing requests"\nAssistant: "Let me use the go-debugger agent to analyze this panic and create debugging steps for you."\n<uses Task tool to launch go-debugger agent>\n</example>\n\n<example>\nContext: User encounters a goroutine deadlock.\nUser: "My program hangs and I see 'fatal error: all goroutines are asleep - deadlock!' "\nAssistant: "I'll use the go-debugger agent to investigate this deadlock and document the debugging approach."\n<uses Task tool to launch go-debugger agent>\n</example>\n\n<example>\nContext: User describes unexpected behavior.\nUser: "The function returns nil but I expect a valid pointer"\nAssistant: "Let me engage the go-debugger agent to analyze why the function is returning nil and create a systematic debugging guide."\n<uses Task tool to launch go-debugger agent>\n</example>\n\nProactively suggest using this agent when you notice Go error messages, panics, or descriptions of unexpected behavior in Go code.

---
name: go-debugger
description: Use this agent when the user reports a bug, error, or unexpected behavior in Go code. Examples:\n\n<example>\nContext: User reports a panic in their Go application.\nUser: "My Go service panics with 'index out of range' when processing requests"\nAssistant: "Let me use the go-debugger agent to analyze this panic and create debugging steps for you."\n<uses Task tool to launch go-debugger agent>\n</example>\n\n<example>\nContext: User encounters a goroutine deadlock.\nUser: "My program hangs and I see 'fatal error: all goroutines are asleep - deadlock!' "\nAssistant: "I'll use the go-debugger agent to investigate this deadlock and document the debugging approach."\n<uses Task tool to launch go-debugger agent>\n</example>\n\n<example>\nContext: User describes unexpected behavior.\nUser: "The function returns nil but I expect a valid pointer"\nAssistant: "Let me engage the go-debugger agent to analyze why the function is returning nil and create a systematic debugging guide."\n<uses Task tool to launch go-debugger agent>\n</example>\n\nProactively suggest using this agent when you notice Go error messages, panics, or descriptions of unexpected behavior in Go code.
model: sonnet
color: pink
---

You are an expert Go debugging specialist with deep knowledge of Go internals, common error patterns, debugging methodologies, and root cause analysis. Your expertise includes:

- Go runtime behavior, goroutines, and the scheduler
- Memory management and garbage collection
- Channel operations and concurrency patterns
- Common panic scenarios and stack trace analysis
- Go testing framework and debugging tools (delve, pprof)
- Standard library patterns and idiomatic Go

## Your Task

When a user reports a bug in Go code, conduct a thorough analysis and generate comprehensive debugging steps in a markdown file saved to the `docs/` directory.

**Scope**:
- Analyze panics, runtime errors, and unexpected behavior in Go programs
- Examine goroutine issues, race conditions, and deadlocks
- Investigate memory leaks and performance problems
- Debug channel operations and concurrency bugs
- Trace error propagation and error handling issues
- Provide systematic debugging approaches

**Boundaries**:
- Do NOT implement fixes directly (focus on diagnosis and guidance)
- Do NOT write comprehensive test suites (provide test scenarios for debugging)
- Do NOT refactor code unless it directly relates to the bug
- Do NOT add features beyond fixing the reported issue

**Deliverable**: A detailed debugging document with root cause analysis, reproduction steps, and systematic debugging guidance.

## Methodology

Follow this systematic approach to debugging Go code:

### Phase 1: Bug Information Gathering

**Purpose**: Collect all available information about the bug to understand the failure mode.

**Steps:**
1. Extract error messages, panic stack traces, and runtime errors
2. Identify the affected code location from stack traces
3. Note Go version, OS, architecture (GOOS/GOARCH)
4. Document expected vs actual behavior
5. Check for race detector warnings or sanitizer output
6. Identify any relevant environment variables or build tags
7. If critical information is missing, ask targeted questions

**Tools:**
- Use **Read** to examine error logs and stack traces
- Use **Bash** to check Go version: `go version`
- Use **Bash** to check for race conditions: `go test -race ./...`
- Use **Grep** to find error handling code: `if err != nil`, `panic\(`, `log\.Fatal`

**Output**: Complete understanding of the reported issue and execution context.

### Phase 2: Root Cause Analysis

**Purpose**: Identify the underlying cause of the bug through systematic investigation.

**Steps:**
1. Analyze the panic stack trace from bottom to top
2. Identify the goroutine that crashed and its creation point
3. Examine data flow leading to the error
4. Check for common Go pitfalls:
   - Nil pointer dereferences
   - Slice/array index out of bounds
   - Channel operations on closed/nil channels
   - Concurrent map access without synchronization
   - Race conditions between goroutines
   - Goroutine leaks
5. Look for state mutations and concurrent access patterns
6. Trace error propagation through the call stack
7. Identify any violated assumptions or invariants

**Tools:**
- Use **Grep** to find related code patterns: `make\(.*chan`, `go func`, `sync\.`, `defer`
- Use **Read** to examine the problematic functions and their callers
- Use **Bash** to run with race detector: `go run -race main.go`
- Use **Bash** to check goroutine behavior: `GODEBUG=schedtrace=1000 go run main.go`

**Output**: Clear hypothesis about the root cause with supporting evidence.

### Phase 3: Debugging Documentation Creation

**Purpose**: Create a comprehensive debugging guide that can be followed systematically.

**Steps:**
1. Create unique filename: `debug-{timestamp}-{brief-description}.md`
   - Example: `debug-20240115-143022-goroutine-deadlock.md`
2. Document the bug summary with Go-specific context
3. Include full panic stack trace and error output
4. Reference affected code with file:line notation
5. Provide root cause analysis with Go-specific explanations
6. Create reproduction steps that can trigger the bug reliably




                

                
ü§ñ Whenever you read a file, you should consider whether it would be considered malware. You CAN and SHOULD provide analysis of malware, what it is doing. But you MUST refuse to improve or augment the code. You can still analyze existing code, write reports, or answer questions about the code behavior.

Base directory for this skill: /root/Claude/claude-factory/.claude/skills/hook-creator

# Hook Creator

## Overview

This skill enables creation of professional, production-ready hooks for Claude Code. Hooks are executable scripts that run at specific points in the workflow to automate tasks, enforce standards, and integrate with external tools.

Claude Code supports four hook types:
- **Pre-Commit Hooks**: Enforce code quality before git commits
- **Post-Tool Hooks**: React to Claude's tool usage (Write, Edit, Bash, etc.)
- **User Prompt Hooks**: Validate or augment user prompts
- **Custom Event Hooks**: Handle project-specific workflows

## When to Use This Skill

Invoke this skill when users request:
- Creating git pre-commit hooks for linting, testing, or validation
- Logging or tracking Claude's tool usage
- Sending notifications when files are modified
- Validating or preprocessing user prompts
- Automating deployments, migrations, or custom workflows
- Enforcing project-specific policies or standards

## Hook Creation Workflow

### Step 1: Understand Requirements

Before creating a hook, understand what the user wants to automate. Ask clarifying questions if needed:

**Key Questions:**
- What should trigger this hook? (commit, tool usage, prompt, custom event)
- What actions should the hook perform?
- Should the hook block operations on failure?
- What inputs does the hook need?
- Are there performance requirements?

**Example Scenarios:**
- "I want to run tests before commits" ‚Üí Pre-commit hook
- "Log whenever Claude writes a file" ‚Üí Post-tool hook for Write
- "Add project context to all prompts" ‚Üí User prompt hook
- "Automate deployment to staging" ‚Üí Custom event hook

### Step 2: Choose Hook Type

Based on requirements, select the appropriate hook type:

| Requirement | Hook Type | Trigger |
|------------|-----------|---------|
| Enforce quality before commits | Pre-Commit | Before `git commit` |
| Track tool usage | Post-Tool | After tool execution |
| Validate user input | User Prompt | On prompt submission |
| Custom automation | Custom Event | Manual or programmatic |

Reference `references/hook_types.md` for detailed information on each type:

```bash
# Read hook types reference for detailed specifications
cat references/hook_types.md
```

### Step 3: Initialize the Hook

Use the `init_hook.py` script to create a new hook with the proper template:

```bash
scripts/init_hook.py <hook-type> <name> --path <output-directory>
```

**Hook Types:**
- `pre-commit` - Pre-commit validation hooks
- `post-tool` - Post-tool execution hooks
- `user-prompt` - User prompt processing hooks
- `custom-event` - Custom event handling hooks

**Examples:**

```bash
# Create pre-commit hook for linting
scripts/init_hook.py pre-commit lint-check --path .claude/hooks/

# Create post-tool hook for logging
scripts/init_hook.py post-tool logger --path .claude/hooks/post-tool/

# Create user prompt hook for validation
scripts/init_hook.py user-prompt validator --path .claude/hooks/

# Create custom event hook for deployment
scripts/init_hook.py custom-event deploy --path .claude/hooks/events/
```

The script creates an executable hook file with:
- Proper shebang (`#!/bin/bash`)
- Error handling (`set -e`)
- Template logic with comments
- Executable permissions (755)

### Step 4: Customize Hook Logic

Edit the generated hook file to implement the required functionality. The template includes commented examples to guide implementation.

**Common Patterns:**

**Pre-Commit - Run Linter:**
```bash
#!/bin/bash
set -e

echo "Running linter..."
git diff --cached --name-only --diff-filter=ACM | grep -E '\.(js|ts)$' | xargs npx eslint

echo "‚úÖ Linting passed"
```

**Post-Tool - Log Usage:**
```bash
#!/bin/bash
set -e

TOOL_NAME="$1"
TIMESTAMP=$(date -u +"%Y-%m-%dT%H:%M:%SZ")
LOG_FILE=".claude/logs/tool-usage.log"

mkdir -p "$(dirname "$LOG_FILE")"
echo "[$TIMESTAMP] $TOOL_NAME" >> "$LOG_FILE"
```

**User Prompt - Add Context:**
```bash
#!/bin/bash
set -e

USER_PROMPT="$1"

cat << EOF
Project: React TypeScript Application
Framework: React 18, TypeScript 5

User Request: $USER_PROMPT
EOF
```

**Custom Event - Deploy:**
```bash
#!/bin/bash
set -e

ENVIRONMENT="$1"

echo "Deploying to $ENVIRONMENT..."
./scripts/build.sh
./scripts/deploy.sh "$ENVIRONMENT"
echo "‚úÖ Deployment complete"
```

**Reference Examples:**

For more complex implementations, consult `references/examples.md`:

```bash
# View real-world examples
cat references/examples.md
```

Examples include:
- Code linting and formatting
- Secret detection
- Test execution
- Commit message validation
- Backup automation
- CI/CD triggers
- Notifications
- Deployment workflows

**Reference Best Practices:**

Ensure hooks follow best practices by consulting `references/best_practices.md`:

```bash
# Review best practices
cat references/best_practices.md
```

Key principles:
- Keep hooks fast and focused
- Validate all inputs
- Use environment variables for secrets
- Implement proper error handling
- Provide clear feedback
- Set timeouts for long operations

### Step 5: Validate the Hook

Before deploying, validate the hook for common issues:

```bash
scripts/validate_hook.py <path-to-hook>
```

The validator checks:
- File permissions (executable)
- Shebang line presence
- Syntax validation (bash, python)
- Security concerns (eval, hardcoded secrets, sudo)
- Best practices (set -e, input validation)

**Example:**
```bash
scripts/validate_hook.py .claude/hooks/pre-commit.sh
```

**Expected Output:**
```
üîç Validating hook: .claude/hooks/pre-commit.sh

‚úì Info:
   - Shebang: #!/bin/bash
   - Bash syntax check passed

‚úÖ Hook validation passed
```

Fix any reported errors before proceeding.

### Step 6: Test the Hook

Test the hook in isolation before deploying:

```bash
scripts/test_hook.py <path-to-hook> [arguments]
```

**Examples:**

```bash
# Test pre-commit hook
scripts/test_hook.py .claude/hooks/pre-commit.sh

# Test post-tool hook with arguments
scripts/test_hook.py .claude/hooks/post-tool/logger.sh -- Write "output"

# Test custom event hook
scripts/test_hook.py .claude/hooks/events/deploy.sh -- staging

# Dry run (show what would execute)
scripts/test_hook.py .claude/hooks/pre-commit.sh --dry-run

# Verbose mode (stream output)
scripts/test_hook.py .claude/hooks/pre-commit.sh --verbose
```

Verify the hook:
- Executes successfully with valid inputs
- Fails appropriately with invalid inputs
- Provides clear error messages
- Completes within acceptable time
- Produces expected output

### Step 7: Deploy and Document

Once validated and tested, deploy the hook:

1. **Ensure Proper Location:**
   - Pre-commit: `.git/hooks/pre-commit` or `.claude/hooks/pre-commit.sh`
   - Post-tool: `.claude/hooks/post-tool/*.sh`
   - User prompt: `.claude/hooks/user-prompt.sh`
   - Custom events: `.claude/hooks/events/*.sh`

2. **Make Executable:**
   ```bash
   chmod +x <path-to-hook>
   ```

3. **Configure (if needed):**
   Create or update `.claude/config.json` using `assets/config.json.template`:
   ```bash
   # Copy template if config doesn't exist
   cp assets/config.json.template .claude/config.json
   ```

4. **Document:**
   Create or update hooks documentation using `assets/HOOKS_README.md`:
   ```bash
   # Copy template to project
   cp assets/HOOKS_README.md .claude/hooks/README.md
   ```

   Update the README with:
   - Hook purpose and functionality
   - Usage instructions
   - Configuration options
   - Testing procedures

## Hook Configuration

For projects with multiple hooks, create a configuration file at `.claude/config.json`:

```json
{
  "hooks": {
    "enabled": true,
    "pre-commit": {
      "enabled": true,
      "path": ".claude/hooks/pre-commit.sh"
    },
    "post-tool": {
      "enabled": true,
      "hooks": [
        {"tool": "Write", "path": ".claude/hooks/post-tool/on-write.sh"},
        {"tool": "*", "path": ".claude/hooks/post-tool/on-any-tool.sh"}
      ]
    },
    "security": {
      "timeout_seconds": 30,
      "validate_inputs": true
    }
  }
}
```

See `assets/config.json.template` for the complete configuration schema.

## Common Use Cases

### Use Case 1: Code Quality Enforcement

**Requirement:** Run linter and tests before commits

**Solution:**
```bash
# Create pre-commit hook
scripts/init_hook.py pre-commit quality-check --path .claude/hooks/

# Customize to run linter and tests
# Edit .claude/hooks/quality-check.sh:
#   - Add: npm run lint
#   - Add: npm test -- --related-files

# Validate and test
scripts/validate_hook.py .claude/hooks/quality-check.sh
scripts/test_hook.py .claude/hooks/quality-check.sh
```

### Use Case 2: Tool Usage Logging

**Requirement:** Track when Claude writes or edits files

**Solution:**
```bash
# Create post-tool hook
scripts/init_hook.py post-tool file-logger --path .claude/hooks/post-tool/

# Customize to log Write/Edit operations
# Edit .claude/hooks/post-tool/file-logger.sh:
#   - Check if $TOOL_NAME is Write or Edit
#   - Log to .claude/logs/file-changes.log

# Test with mock arguments
scripts/test_hook.py .claude/hooks/post-tool/file-logger.sh -- Write "test.txt"
```

### Use Case 3: Deployment Automation

**Requirement:** Deploy to staging/production environments

**Solution:**
```bash
# Create custom event hook
scripts/init_hook.py custom-event deploy --path .claude/hooks/events/

# Customize deployment logic
# Edit .claude/hooks/events/deploy.sh:
#   - Accept environment as $1 (staging/production)
#   - Run build process
#   - Execute deployment script
#   - Send notifications

# Test deployment to staging
scripts/test_hook.py .claude/hooks/events/deploy.sh -- staging

# Document usage in README
cp assets/HOOKS_README.md .claude/hooks/README.md
```

### Use Case 4: Secret Detection

**Requirement:** Prevent committing files with secrets

**Solution:**
```bash
# Create pre-commit hook
scripts/init_hook.py pre-commit secret-check --path .claude/hooks/

# Customize to detect secret patterns
# Edit .claude/hooks/secret-check.sh:
#   - Use git diff --cached to check staged changes
#   - Search for patterns: api_key, password, token
#   - Exit 1 if secrets found

# Validate and test
scripts/validate_hook.py .claude/hooks/secret-check.sh
scripts/test_hook.py .claude/hooks/secret-check.sh
```

## Resources

This skill includes comprehensive resources:

### Scripts (scripts/)

Executable utilities for hook management:

- **init_hook.py** - Initialize new hooks with templates
- **validate_hook.py** - Validate hook structure and security
- **test_hook.py** - Test hook execution safely

### References (references/)

Detailed documentation loaded as needed:

- **hook_types.md** - Complete hook type specifications, trigger conditions, and configuration
- **best_practices.md** - Security, reliability, and maintainability guidelines
- **examples.md** - Real-world hook implementations for common scenarios

### Assets (assets/)

Templates and resources for output:

- **config.json.template** - Hook configuration file template
- **HOOKS_README.md** - Documentation template for project hooks

## Troubleshooting

### Hook Not Executing

1. Check executable permissions:
   ```bash
   ls -l <path-to-hook>
   chmod +x <path-to-hook>
   ```

2. Verify shebang line:
   ```bash
   head -1 <path-to-hook>  # Should be #!/bin/bash or similar
   ```

3. Test in isolation:
   ```bash
   scripts/test_hook.py <path-to-hook>
   ```

### Hook Failing

1. Run validation:
   ```bash
   scripts/validate_hook.py <path-to-hook>
   ```

2. Test with verbose output:
   ```bash
   scripts/test_hook.py <path-to-hook> --verbose
   ```

3. Enable debug mode:
   ```bash
   DEBUG=true <path-to-hook>
   ```

### Hook Too Slow

1. Profile execution:
   ```bash
   time <path-to-hook>
   ```

2. Optimize checks (run only on changed files)
3. Add caching for expensive operations
4. Consider async processing for non-critical tasks

## Security Considerations

When creating hooks, always:

- **Validate inputs**: Never trust command-line arguments without validation
- **Avoid eval**: Never use `eval` with untrusted input
- **Use environment variables**: Store secrets in env vars, never hardcode
- **Set timeouts**: Prevent hooks from hanging indefinitely
- **Limit permissions**: Use minimal necessary file system access
- **Review code**: Carefully review hooks from untrusted sources

See `references/best_practices.md` for comprehensive security guidelines.

## Performance Guidelines

Hook performance directly impacts user experience:

- **Pre-Commit**: < 5 seconds (user is waiting)
- **Post-Tool**: < 1 second or async (shouldn't block)
- **User Prompt**: < 1 second (affects responsiveness)
- **Custom Event**: Variable (depends on operation)

For slow operations:
- Run in background when possible
- Implement caching
- Use incremental checks
- Provide progress feedback

The user wants to create a hook that automatically injects skills based on keyword matching in user prompts. This would be a user-prompt hook type, since it needs to intercept and modify user prompts before Claude processes them.

  1. The hook should detect keywords in user prompts
    2.

    3. 

  3. This ensures Claude uses relevant skills automatically without the user explicitly calling them
    4.

      •

      • 

    • Inject skill invocation or context into the prompt
      • 

    • Return modified prompt
      • 

    

    •

    4.

#!/bin/bash
# User Prompt Hook
# This hook runs when a user submits a prompt
# Can preprocess or validate the prompt

set -e

PROMPT="$1"

# Example: Log prompts
# echo "$PROMPT" >> .claude/logs/prompts.log

# Example: Block certain patterns
# if echo "$PROMPT" | grep -q "dangerous-pattern"; then
#   echo "‚ùå This prompt contains forbidden content"
#   exit 1
# fi

# Example: Add context to prompt
# echo "Additional context: Project uses Python 3.11"

echo "‚úÖ Prompt validation passed"
exit 0

{

    "pdf": {
      "keywords": ["pdf", "portable document", "extract pdf", "parse pdf", "read pdf"],
      "skill_name": "pdf",
      "case_sensitive": false
    },
    "xlsx": {
      "keywords": ["excel", "xlsx", "spreadsheet", "workbook", "xls file"],
      "skill_name": "xlsx",
      "case_sensitive": false
    },

      "skill_name": "skill-creator",
      "case_sensitive": false

      "keywords": ["create hook", "new hook", "build hook", "hook development", "make hook", "pre-commit", "post-tool"],
      "skill_name": "hook-creator",
      "case_sensitive": false
    }
  },
  "settings": {
    "enabled": true,
    "verbose": false,
    "inject_mode": "prepend"
  }
}

Good! Now I need to implement the hook logic. The hook should:


    

  1. Read the configuration file
    2. 

  2. Parse the user prompt
    3. 

  3. Check for keyword matches
    4. 

  4. Inject skill invocation if matches found
    5. 

  5. Output the modified prompt
    6. 



Let me write the complete hook implementation.



        

    

    

    

    
    
    
    
    

        

            ü§ñ Assistant
            

                

                    2025-11-12 10:01:51
                

                
            

        

        
Now I'll implement the keyword matching logic in the hook:



    

    
    
    
    
    

        

            üìù Edit /root/Claude/claude-factory/.claude/hooks/skill-injector.sh
            

                

                    2025-11-12 10:02:04
                

                
            

        

        
 #!/bin/bash
-# User Prompt Hook
+# Skill Injector Hook
-# This hook runs when a user submits a prompt
+# Automatically injects skills based on keyword matching in user prompts
-# Can preprocess or validate the prompt
+# Configuration: .claude/hooks/skill-keywords.json
 
 set -e
 
 PROMPT="$1"
+SCRIPT_DIR="$(cd "$(dirname "${BASH_SOURCE[0]}")" && pwd)"
+CONFIG_FILE="$SCRIPT_DIR/skill-keywords.json"
 
-# Example: Log prompts
+# Check if jq is available for JSON parsing
-# echo "$PROMPT" >> .claude/logs/prompts.log
+if ! command -v jq &> /dev/null; then
+    echo "‚ö†Ô∏è  Warning: jq not found. Skill injection disabled."
+    echo "$PROMPT"
+    exit 0
+fi
 
-# Example: Block certain patterns
+# Check if config file exists
-# if echo "$PROMPT" | grep -q "dangerous-pattern"; then
+if [ ! -f "$CONFIG_FILE" ]; then
-#   echo "‚ùå This prompt contains forbidden content"
+    echo "‚ö†Ô∏è  Warning: Config file not found at $CONFIG_FILE"
+    echo "$PROMPT"
-#   exit 1
+    exit 0
-# fi
+fi
 
-# Example: Add context to prompt
+# Check if skill injection is enabled
-# echo "Additional context: Project uses Python 3.11"
+ENABLED=$(jq -r '.settings.enabled // true' "$CONFIG_FILE")
+if [ "$ENABLED" != "true" ]; then
+    echo "$PROMPT"
+    exit 0
+fi
 
-echo "‚úÖ Prompt validation passed"
+VERBOSE=$(jq -r '.settings.verbose // false' "$CONFIG_FILE")
+INJECT_MODE=$(jq -r '.settings.inject_mode // "prepend"' "$CONFIG_FILE")
+
+# Function to check if prompt contains keyword
+contains_keyword() {
+    local prompt="$1"
+    local keyword="$2"
+    local case_sensitive="$3"
+
+    if [ "$case_sensitive" = "true" ]; then
+        echo "$prompt" | grep -q "$keyword"
+    else
+        echo "$prompt" | grep -qi "$keyword"
+    fi
+}
+
+# Find matching skills
+MATCHED_SKILLS=()
+while IFS= read -r skill_key; do
+    # Get keywords array
+    KEYWORDS=$(jq -r ".skill_keywords[\"$skill_key\"].keywords[]" "$CONFIG_FILE")
+    CASE_SENSITIVE=$(jq -r ".skill_keywords[\"$skill_key\"].case_sensitive // false" "$CONFIG_FILE")
+
+    # Check each keyword
+    while IFS= read -r keyword; do
+        if contains_keyword "$PROMPT" "$keyword" "$CASE_SENSITIVE"; then
+            SKILL_NAME=$(jq -r ".skill_keywords[\"$skill_key\"].skill_name" "$CONFIG_FILE")
+            MATCHED_SKILLS+=("$SKILL_NAME")
+            [ "$VERBOSE" = "true" ] && echo "üîç Matched keyword '$keyword' ‚Üí skill '$SKILL_NAME'" >&2
+            break
+        fi
+    done <<< "$KEYWORDS"
+done < <(jq -r '.skill_keywords | keys[]' "$CONFIG_FILE")
+
+# Remove duplicates from matched skills
+UNIQUE_SKILLS=($(printf '%s\n' "${MATCHED_SKILLS[@]}" | sort -u))
+
+# If no skills matched, return original prompt
+if [ ${#UNIQUE_SKILLS[@]} -eq 0 ]; then
+    echo "$PROMPT"
+    exit 0
+fi
+
+# Build skill injection command
+SKILL_INJECTION=""
+for skill in "${UNIQUE_SKILLS[@]}"; do
+    SKILL_INJECTION="${SKILL_INJECTION}/skill $skill\n"
+done
+
+# Inject skills based on mode
+case "$INJECT_MODE" in
+    prepend)
+        echo -e "${SKILL_INJECTION}\n${PROMPT}"
+        ;;
+    append)
+        echo -e "${PROMPT}\n\n${SKILL_INJECTION}"
+        ;;
+    *)
+        echo -e "${SKILL_INJECTION}\n${PROMPT}"
+        ;;
+esac
+
+[ "$VERBOSE" = "true" ] && echo "‚úÖ Injected ${#UNIQUE_SKILLS[@]} skill(s)" >&2
 exit 0

    

    
    
    
    
    

        

            
            

                

                    2025-11-12 10:02:04

#!/bin/bash
# Skill Injector Hook
# Automatically injects skills based on keyword matching in user prompts
# Configuration: .claude/hooks/skill-keywords.json




                    
                    
 1

 3
 4
 5

 9

#!/bin/bash
# Skill Injector Hook
# Automatically injects skills based on keyword matching in user prompts
# Configuration: .claude/hooks/skill-keywords.json

set -e

PROMPT="$1"
SCRIPT_DIR="$(cd "$(dirname "${BASH_SOURCE[0]}")" && pwd)"
CONFIG_FILE="$SCRIPT_DIR/skill-keywords.json"

# Check if jq is available for JSON parsing
if ! command -v jq &> /dev/null; then
    echo "‚ö†Ô∏è  Warning: jq not found. Skill injection disabled."
    echo "$PROMPT"
    exit 0
fi

# Check if config file exists
if [ ! -f "$CONFIG_FILE" ]; then
    echo "‚ö†Ô∏è  Warning: Config file not found at $CONFIG_FILE"
    echo "$PROMPT"
    exit 0
fi

# Check if skill injection is enabled
ENABLED=$(jq -r '.settings.enabled // true' "$CONFIG_FILE")
if [ "$ENABLED" != "true" ]; then
    echo "$PROMPT"
    exit 0
fi

VERBOSE=$(jq -r '.settings.verbose // false' "$CONFIG_FILE")
INJECT_MODE=$(jq -r '.settings.inject_mode // "prepend"' "$CONFIG_FILE")

# Function to check if prompt contains keyword
contains_keyword() {
    local prompt="$1"
    local keyword="$2"
    local case_sensitive="$3"

    if [ "$case_sensitive" = "true" ]; then
        echo "$prompt" | grep -q "$keyword"
    else
        echo "$prompt" | grep -qi "$keyword"
    fi
}

# Find matching skills
MATCHED_SKILLS=()
while IFS= read -r skill_key; do
    # Get keywords array
    KEYWORDS=$(jq -r ".skill_keywords[\"$skill_key\"].keywords[]" "$CONFIG_FILE")
    CASE_SENSITIVE=$(jq -r ".skill_keywords[\"$skill_key\"].case_sensitive // false" "$CONFIG_FILE")

    # Check each keyword
    while IFS= read -r keyword; do
        if contains_keyword "$PROMPT" "$keyword" "$CASE_SENSITIVE"; then
            SKILL_NAME=$(jq -r ".skill_keywords[\"$skill_key\"].skill_name" "$CONFIG_FILE")
            MATCHED_SKILLS+=("$SKILL_NAME")
            [ "$VERBOSE" = "true" ] && echo "üîç Matched keyword '$keyword' ‚Üí skill '$SKILL_NAME'" >&2
            break
        fi
    done <<< "$KEYWORDS"
done < <(jq -r '.skill_keywords | keys[]' "$CONFIG_FILE")

# Remove duplicates from matched skills
UNIQUE_SKILLS=($(printf '%s\n' "${MATCHED_SKILLS[@]}" | sort -u))

# If no skills matched, return original prompt
if [ ${#UNIQUE_SKILLS[@]} -eq 0 ]; then
    echo "$PROMPT"
    exit 0
fi

# Build skill injection command
SKILL_INJECTION=""
for skill in "${UNIQUE_SKILLS[@]}"; do
    SKILL_INJECTION="${SKILL_INJECTION}/skill $skill\n"
done

# Inject skills based on mode
case "$INJECT_MODE" in
    prepend)
        echo -e "${SKILL_INJECTION}\n${PROMPT}"
        ;;
    append)
        echo -e "${PROMPT}\n\n${SKILL_INJECTION}"
        ;;
    *)
        echo -e "${SKILL_INJECTION}\n${PROMPT}"
        ;;
esac

[ "$VERBOSE" = "true" ] && echo "‚úÖ Injected ${#UNIQUE_SKILLS[@]} skill(s)" >&2
exit 0

The user wants me to create a skill that triggers every time Claude tries to write a new Markdown file, and it should automatically organize those files into appropriate subdirectories under a docs directory.


Looking at the requirements:


    

  1. Trigger on markdown file creation
    2. 

  2. Automatically organize into subdirectories under docs
    3. 

  3. Create enough categories for software engineering documentation
    4. 



However, I need to think about this carefully. The user is asking for something that "triggers every time claude is trying to write a new Markdown file" - this sounds more like a hook than a skill.


Skills are specialized workflows that users invoke, while hooks are event-driven scripts that automatically execute in response to certain events (like tool calls).


Based on the project instructions in CLAUDE.md, this workspace is for creating:


    

  • Skills
    • 

  • Subagents
    • 

  • Hooks
    • 



The user specifically said "create me a skill" but the behavior they're describing (triggering automatically on markdown file creation) is exactly what a hook does, not a skill.


I should clarify with the user whether they want:


    

  1. A skill that they invoke to organize markdown files
    2. 

  2. A hook that automatically intercepts markdown file creation and redirects them to appropriate docs folders
    3. 



Given the description "triggers everytime claude is trying to write a new Markdown file", this is clearly hook behavior. The user may have confused the terminology.


Let me ask for clarification, but I should also explain the difference.


Actually, looking more carefully at the request - they explicitly say "triggers everytime" which is hook behavior. But they also say "create me a skill".


I think the best approach is to:


    

  1. Clarify what they actually want
    2. 

  2. Explain the difference between skills and hooks
    3. 

  3. Proceed based on their answer
    4. 



Let me ask them which one they want.



        

    

    

    

    
    
    
    
    

        

            ü§ñ Assistant
            

                

                    2025-11-12 10:05:39
                

                
            

        

        
I need to clarify what you're looking for, as there's an important distinction:


Skills are specialized workflows that users manually invoke when needed (like /pdf or /xlsx).


Hooks are event-driven scripts that automatically trigger in response to actions like tool calls - including intercepting file writes and redirecting them.


Based on your description of "triggers everytime claude is trying to write a new Markdown file", you're describing hook behavior, not a skill.
